There hasn't been much buying conviction in the broader market, although the small-cap Russell 2000 (+0.5%) has seen some positive action. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.2%, and the Nasdaq Composite is down 0.4%.Several factors that have contributed to the negative disposition include President Trump saying there are no signs of China buying U.S. agricultural products, some cautious trading ahead of Apple's (AAPL 208.08, -1.59, -0.8%) earnings report after the close and the Fed's rate decision tomorrow, and the disappointing price action in shares of Beyond Meat (BYND 205.01, -17.12, -7.7%) following its report.Beyond Meat is perhaps more a reflection of how far many stocks, and the stock market to a certain extent, have come in a short period of time. It isn't too surprising to see some broader consolidation -- or to see shares of Beyond Meat attempting a recovery after being down as much as 17% today.The stock market, too, has come off its lows. At this juncture, the utilities (-0.7%), information technology (-0.6%), and consumer discretionary (-0.6%) sectors are underperforming, while the materials (+0.5%), real estate (+0.5%), energy (+0.5%), and consumer staples (+0.4%) sectors are outperforming.In corporate news, Procter & Gamble (PG 121.29, +5.29, +4.6%) and Merck (MRK 83.42, +0.94, +1.1%) both beat top and bottom-line estimates. Shares are up nicely on the results, while shares of fellow Dow component Pfizer (PFE 39.02, -2.44) are down 5.9% after being downgraded at Bank of America/Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley. Capital One (COF 89.99, -6.93, -7.2%), meanwhile, is feeling the fallout from a data breach that affected over 100 million customers.Separately, an expectation that interest rates will remain low has prompted Goldman Sachs to raise its S&P 500 2019 year-end target to 3100 and set a 2020 year-end price target of 3400. Currently, the benchmark 10-yr note yield is up one basis point to 2.07%.Reviewing today's economic data, which included the Personal Income and Spending Report for June, the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for July, the S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May, and Pending Home Sales for June:Personal income increased 0.4% (Briefing.com consensus 0.4%) while personal spending rose 0.3% (Briefing.com consensus 0.3%) m/m in June. The PCE Price Index was up 0.1%, as expected, and the core PCE price Index, which excludes food and energy, jumped 0.2%, also as expected. On a yr/yr basis, the PCE Price Index held steady at 1.4% while the core PCE Price Index edged up to 1.6% from 1.5% in May.The key takeaway from the report is that it contained decent consumer data and tame inflation data, which is not all that surprising relative to recent data seen of late.The Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index surged to 135.7 in July (Briefing.com consensus 125.5) from an upwardly revised 124.3 (from 121.5) in June. That is the highest reading since November 2018 and the third-highest reading since October 2000.The key takeaway from the report is that consumers are optimistic about current and prospective business and labor market conditions, and have improved expectations for their financial outlook. That is a supportive combination that will encourage increased consumer spending activity.The S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May increased 2.4% (Briefing.com consensus 3.5%) after increasing 2.5% in April.Pending Home Sales increased 1.6% in June (Briefing.com consensus +1.0%). DAX...12253.4...-164.10...-1.30%.16:15 ETDow +28.90 at 27221.35, Nasdaq -36.88 at 8293.33, S&P -4.89 at 3020.97[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 lost 0.2% on Monday, slipping from record highs in a lackluster session. The Nasdaq Composite (-0.4%) and Russell 2000 (-0.6%) both underperformed, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.1%) managed to finish higher.Monday's session didn't include much price action, as investors appeared to be waiting for several key events later this week. Some of these events will include the FOMC's rate decision, U.S.-China trade talks, the July employment report, and Apple's (AAPL 209.68, +1.94, +0.9%) earnings report. On a related note, Apple's price target was raised to $235 from $225 at UBS before its results after Tuesday's close.Apple shares rose on the increased price target, but the broader market was still weighed down by widely-held shares of Amazon (AMZN 1912.45, -30.60, -1.6%), Facebook (FB 195.94, -3.81, -1.9%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1239.41, -11.00, -0.9%). In turn, the S&P 500 consumer discretionary (-0.6%) and communication services (-0.5%) sectors were among today's laggards but, like the broader market, finished the session off intraday lows.The S&P 500 financials sector (-0.8%) succumbed to broad-based selling interest throughout the day. Wells Fargo (WFC 48.28, -1.02, -2.1%) was a notable laggard amid a Wall Street Journal report indicating that the Trump administration plans to make it harder for deeply indebted borrowers to acquire mortgage loans.On the other hand, the S&P 500 defensive-oriented sectors -- utilities (+0.5%), real estate (+0.5%), health care (+0.4%), and consumer staples (+0.3%) -- were the lone sectors that finished higher.Separately, Mylan N.V. (MYL 20.78, +2.32, +12.6%) agreed to combine with Pfizer's (PFE 41.45, -1.64, -3.8%) off-patent drug business, giving Mylan shareholders 43% of the combined company. On a related note, Mylan N.V. beat top and bottom-line estimates; Pfizer beat earnings estimates but missed revenue estimates.U.S. Treasuries finished the session higher, pushing yields lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield declined three basis points each to 1.84% and 2.06%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index finished flat at 98.04. WTI crude increased 1.2% to $56.87/bbl.Investors did not receive any notable economic data on Monday.Looking ahead, Tuesday will feature the Personal Income and Spending report for June, which will include the Fed's preferred inflation gauge -- the PCE Price Index. Investors will also receive the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for July, Pending Home Sales for June, and the S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May.Nasdaq Composite +25.0% YTDS&P 500 +20.5% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +16.7% YTDRussell 2000 +16.4% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1472/1420. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1183/1867.Briefing.com is the leading Internet provider of live market analysis for U.S. Stock, U.S. Bond and world FX market participants. 1-800-752-3013 or http://www.briefing.comLoad-Date: July 30, 2019End of Document

S&P: -7.79...NYSE Vol: 775.8 mln.. Adv: 1728.. Dec: 1168Nasdaq Vol: 1.8 bln.. Adv: 1883.. Dec: 1170Moving the MarketSector WatchWall Street closes slightly lower in front of Apple's (AAPL) earnings report after the close and the Fed's rate decision tomorrowPresident Trump calls out China for not buying U.S. agricultural products; trade talks expected to wrap up tomorrow in Shanghai Consumer confidence for July climbs above expectationsStrong: Energy, Real Estate, Materials, IndustrialsWeak: Utilities, Information Technology, Consumer Discretionary, Communication Services16:15 ETDow -23.33 at 27198.02, Nasdaq -19.71 at 8273.62, S&P -7.79 at 3013.18[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market wavered mostly in negative territory on Tuesday, leaving the S&P 500 (-0.3%), Dow Jones Industrial Average (-0.1%), and Nasdaq Composite (-0.2%) with slight losses. There weren't too many positive catalysts for the broader market, but the small-cap Russell 2000 did advance 1.1% to finish near session highs.The S&P 500's worst levels of the day came shortly after the open, as investors appeared uninterested to participate in the action in front of Apple's (AAPL 208.78, -0.90, -0.4%) earnings report after the close and the FOMC's rate decision tomorrow. President Trump alleging that China has yet to buy U.S. agricultural products added to the negative tone.Still, aside from some profit taking in hot-flying stocks like Beyond Meat (BYND 194.76, -27.37, -12.3%) and Under Armour (UAA 24.08, -3.36, -12.2%) following their earnings reports, there was no serious interest to withdraw from the broader market. At its low, the S&P 500 was down 0.7% and hanging just above the 3000 level, where it would firmly stay above the rest of the day.The final standings reflected a mixed session with five S&P 500 sectors finishing higher and six sectors finishing lower. The utilities (-0.8%), information technology (-0.7%), and consumer discretionary (-0.7%) sectors underperformed, while the energy (+1.1%), real estate (+0.9%), and materials (+0.6%) sectors finished on top.Energy stocks gained traction as oil prices ($58.05, +1.18, +2.1%) made a big move in the afternoon on no confirmed news catalyst. The noticeable gain today could have been derived from speculation that the Fed's expected rate cut tomorrow could increase demand for oil.In other corporate news, Procter & Gamble (PG 120.41, +4.41, +3.8%) and Merck (MRK 83.27, +0.78, +1.0%) pleased investors with their earnings results. Pfizer (PFE 38.79, -2.66) fell 6.4% after the stock was downgraded at both Bank of America/Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley. Capital One (COF 91.21, -5.71) fell 5.9% after disclosing a data breach that affected over 100 million customers.U.S. Treasuries finished slightly lower in another muted session. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield increased one basis point each to 1.85% and 2.06%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index finished unchanged at 98.05.Reviewing Tuesday's economic data, which included the Personal Income and Spending Report for June, the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for July, the S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May, and Pending Home Sales for June:Personal income increased 0.4% (Briefing.com consensus 0.4%) while personal spending rose 0.3% (Briefing.com consensus 0.3%) m/m in June. The PCE Price Index was up 0.1%, as expected, and the core PCE price Index, which excludes food and energy, jumped 0.2%, also as expected. On a yr/yr basis, the PCE Price Index held steady at 1.4% while the core PCE Price Index edged up to 1.6% from 1.5% in May.The key takeaway from the report is that it contained decent consumer data and tame inflation data, which is not all that surprising relative to recent data seen of late.The Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index surged to 135.7 in July (Briefing.com consensus 125.5) from an upwardly revised 124.3 (from 121.5) in June. That is the highest reading since November 2018 and the third-highest reading since October 2000.The key takeaway from the report is that consumers are optimistic about current and prospective business and labor market conditions, and have improved expectations for their financial outlook. That is a supportive combination that will encourage increased consumer spending activity.The S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May increased 2.4% (Briefing.com consensus 3.5%) after increasing 2.5% in April.Pending Home Sales increased 1.6% in June (Briefing.com consensus +1.0%). Today's reading follows an unrevised increase of 1.1% in May.Looking ahead, investors will receive the FOMC rate decision, the ADP Employment Change report for July, the Chicago PMI for July, the Employment Cost Index for the second quarter, and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index on Wednesday.Nasdaq Composite +24.7% YTDS&P 500 +20.2% YTDRussell 2000 +17.6% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +16.6% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1728/1168. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1883/1170.15:25 ETDow -42.10 at 27179.25, Nasdaq -20.65 at 8272.68, S&P -9.63 at 3011.34[BRIEFING.COM] Metals Settlement Prices:December gold settled up $10.80 (0.8%) at $1444.10/ozSeptember silver settled up $0.165 higher (1.0%) at $16.605/ozSeptember copper settled down $0.0405 lower (0.1%) at $2.677/lbAgriculture Settlement Prices:Sept corn settled $0.05 lower at $4.11/bushelSept wheat settled $0.06 lower at $4.97/bushelNov soybeans settled $0.07 lower at $8.96/bushelEnergy Settlement Prices:September Crude Oil futures rose $1.18 (2.1%) to $58.05/barrelSept Natural Gas rose $0.021 (0.1%) at $2.137/MMBtuSept RBOB Gasoline rose $0.0307 (0.2%) at $1.846/gallonSept Heating Oil rose $0.0323 (0.2%) at $1.9526/gallon ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1655/1279. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1865/1163.14:55 ETDow -29.91 at 27191.44, Nasdaq -13.04 at 8280.29, S&P -7.52 at 3013.45[BRIEFING.COM] Some of the prior trade-related enthusiasm has eased a bit, leaving the S&P 500 down 0.3% for the moment.It should be noted that President Trump did not specify when he spoke with his Chinese counterpart, but it was still soothing for the market to hear. There hasn't been much buying conviction in the broader market, although the small-cap Russell 2000 (+0.5%) has seen some positive action. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.2%, and the Nasdaq Composite is down 0.4%.Several factors that have contributed to the negative disposition include President Trump saying there are no signs of China buying U.S. agricultural products, some cautious trading ahead of Apple's (AAPL 208.08, -1.59, -0.8%) earnings report after the close and the Fed's rate decision tomorrow, and the disappointing price action in shares of Beyond Meat (BYND 205.01, -17.12, -7.7%) following its report.Beyond Meat is perhaps more a reflection of how far many stocks, and the stock market to a certain extent, have come in a short period of time. It isn't too surprising to see some broader consolidation -- or to see shares of Beyond Meat attempting a recovery after being down as much as 17% today.The stock market, too, has come off its lows. At this juncture, the utilities (-0.7%), information technology (-0.6%), and consumer discretionary (-0.6%) sectors are underperforming, while the materials (+0.5%), real estate (+0.5%), energy (+0.5%), and consumer staples (+0.4%) sectors are outperforming.In corporate news, Procter & Gamble (PG 121.29, +5.29, +4.6%) and Merck (MRK 83.42, +0.94, +1.1%) both beat top and bottom-line estimates. The Nasdaq Composite (-0.4%) and Russell 2000 (-0.6%) both underperformed, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.1%) managed to finish higher.Monday's session didn't include much price action, as investors appeared to be waiting for several key events later this week. Some of these events will include the FOMC's rate decision, U.S.-China trade talks, the July employment report, and Apple's (AAPL 209.68, +1.94, +0.9%) earnings report. On a related note, Apple's price target was raised to $235 from $225 at UBS before its results after Tuesday's close.Apple shares rose on the increased price target, but the broader market was still weighed down by widely-held shares of Amazon (AMZN 1912.45, -30.60, -1.6%), Facebook (FB 195.94, -3.81, -1.9%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1239.41, -11.00, -0.9%). In turn, the S&P 500 consumer discretionary (-0.6%) and communication services (-0.5%) sectors were among today's laggards but, like the broader market, finished the session off intraday lows.The S&P 500 financials sector (-0.8%) succumbed to broad-based selling interest throughout the day. Wells Fargo (WFC 48.28, -1.02, -2.1%) was a notable laggard amid a Wall Street Journal report indicating that the Trump administration plans to make it harder for deeply indebted borrowers to acquire mortgage loans.On the other hand, the S&P 500 defensive-oriented sectors -- utilities (+0.5%), real estate (+0.5%), health care (+0.4%), and consumer staples (+0.3%) -- were the lone sectors that finished higher.Separately, Mylan N.V. (MYL 20.78, +2.32, +12.6%) agreed to combine with Pfizer's (PFE 41.45, -1.64, -3.8%) off-patent drug business, giving Mylan shareholders 43% of the combined company. Dollar exceeds $20 for EU-China conflictCE Noticias Financieras EnglishAugust 6, 2019 TuesdayCopyright 2019 Content Engine, LLC.All Rights ReservedCopyright 2019 CE Noticias Financieras All Rights ReservedLength: 312 wordsBodyThe Universal/Tláloc PugaThe dollar surpassed 20 pesos for the first time in the past two months, because investors are concerned about trade problems between the United States and China. The currency was sold yesterday afternoon at 20.02 pesos on CitiBanamex and meant the most expensive price since June 6th, when it was then trading at 20.05 units.This is an uptick of 40 cents compared to Friday, the biggest rise in a single day since the end of May. The dollar has risen 65 cents since Wednesday last week, due to trade tensions between the world's two largest economies, as well as the eventual impact this can have on the global economy.The Chinese government yesterday allowed the yuan to fall below the threshold of seven units per dollar, for the first time in more than a decade, as US President Donald Trump described as a "great violation."Last Friday, the Asian country asked state-owned companies to suspend american union purchases of agricultural products, after days earlier Trump surprised with the announcement of a new 10% tariff on Chinese goods valued at $300 billion 1 September, ending any truce in the trade dispute. Reuters figures indicate that the wholesale dollar went on to be listed last night at 19.73 pesos in international negotiations, where more transactions are made with the Mexican currency.Fears of a global slowdown, in the face of the U.S.-China trade struggle, also threw oil and stock exchanges. The Mexican mix finished at $52.32 yesterday, the lowest price since January 28, and has lost more than seven dollars since Wednesday. The Mexican Stock Exchange finished in 39 thousand 502 points, its second day followed below 40 thousand units. The stock market crash in Mexico went hand in hand with its peers in the United States. Industrial Dow Jones and the S&P; 500 sank more than 2%, while the Nasdaq slumped 3.5 percent. Load-Date: August 7, 2019End of Document

Apple's Strong 3Q Earnings; 2020 Dems Debate in Detroit; Capital One Data Breach; Countdown to the Federal Reserve Decision; College Financial Aid ScamMORNINGS WITH MARIA MORNINGS WITH MARIA 7:00 AM ESTJuly 31, 2019 WednesdayCopyright 2019 Fox Business Network LLC All Rights Reserved Section: NEWS; FinancialLength: 8054 wordsByline: Maria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Hillary Vaughn, Deirdre Bolton, Cheryl Casone, Juan WilliamsGuests: Matt Murray, Lindsey Bell, Angelo Zino, Keith Banks, Peter MoriciBodyMARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Mnuchin and Lighthizer are in Shanghai today.Markets this morning globally are mixed. Take a look at the European indices. And no increases in tariffs.And I think as long as we can drag this thing out, these companies are able to deal with the tariffs that are currently in place.BARTIROMO: But the longer we go without a USMCA deal ratified is going to be unnerving, right? I'll double check that. I think it's 18, 19 -- 18 seats but I'll check it.BARTIROMO: We're watching the economy. Customers holding on to their smartphones longer weighing on the results as well.Having said that, the stock is up this morning, four and a third percent on Apple $217.75.Joining us right now is CFRA research senior equity analyst, Angelo Zino. I think kind of the key for Apple as well as, you know, for the broader, you know, coverage area that I cover is, you know, companies are beating fairly low - - a very low bar, in terms of guidance as well.I mean the expectations have been fairly low and they're exceeding those expectations. I think a lot of that specifically is coming out of China. I think, you know, you're seeing better than -- you know, numbers coming out of that region specifically.BARTIROMO: Yes. Because it's the guidance that everybody cares about. What do they think about the rest of the year and going into 2020, right? And the guidance you say has been a little better than expected.ZINO: Yes, absolutely. So when we look at, you know, Apple specifically, if we were to take kind of the one big takeaway out of the quarter, it really does come down to China. China was down 4 percent year over year this quarter compared to down 22 percent and down 27 percent the last two quarters.So again, you know, the trajectory much better than expected. We expected stabilization out of China to start coming closer to the December quarter when you started seeing kind of the more favorable comps on that side of things, came two quarters earlier than we anticipated.MURRAY: Angelo, broadly how does the global economy look for a lot of the companies you're following? China as you say is an issue, they really slowed down. Europe is not in good shape. Yes, the U.S. is hanging in pretty well at this point but how long can the U.S. keep powering growth for companies?ZINO: Yes, it's interesting. I think, you know, from a broader level, the U.S. and Europe have hung in there. We are seeing some pockets of weakness, I'd say from some of the supply chain names in areas -- in certain areas of the U.S. and Europe -- areas like autos potentially.But that being said, listen, I think it hangs in there. I do think the order trajectory in China is starting to see some notable improvement in the supply chain. So even if we were to see some softness come out of the U.S. and Europe, I think that's more than offset in potential better than expected results coming out of China.BARTIROMO: Well, we haven't seen a lot of growth out of Europe. No, I mean, you know, as far as Europe is concerned too, to your point, I mean there's been essentially no growth coming out of there. And we think that just continues in the foreseeable future.BELL: Angelo -- you and I were talking yesterday before the Apple report about the Huawei report that came out that revenue was up 23 percent in the first half, they're taking market share over there in China. And you said to me, you see this as a positive for Apple. Can you explain why?ZINO: Yes. No. So when we think about what's going on in China for Apple, they've made some moves on their end that you know, we think it's really helped them, whether it be trade-in programs, whether it be financing options for the consumer to make things more affordable. But I think when you look out at Huawei's results and now, you know, Apple's results, I think it tells you that the consumer is actually coming back in China.And I think that's really kind of helping Apple's results. I think that's helping a lot of the consumer-oriented names as well.BARTIROMO: Yes. By the way, we also saw the consumer strong in the GDP last week. It was the consumer that was driving the GDP last week, not the business sector.MCDOWELL: In China, do we need to watch out for disinformation campaigns out of the Chinese government about Apple, Huawei -- I brought up --BARTIROMO: I think you're right about that.MCDOWELL: -- touting, because again, that's not something that you would necessarily see on the surface but it bubbles up from wherever in China. But also with Huawei touting itself as the patriotic option in the country. So what should we watch out for in terms of hazards?ZINO: Yes, absolutely. So when we think about the two biggest risks for Apple in general, one is the China market. The other is the regulatory issues because of that services business growing. But when we think about China, clearly it has one to do with trade and what's going on with -- on the trades side of things.But our view is the bigger risk in China continues to be -- if you look at Samsung a couple years ago, they once owned 20 percent of the market. They now own less than 1 percent of the market in China. They've essentially been thrown out because of Huawei at the low-end of the market as well as the high-end of the market between Huawei and Apple.And, you know, when we kind of look at what the risk here is for Apple here in China, I think it potentially is them continuing to lose market share. At one point had north 15 percent share. They now have less than 10 percent of the market.BARTIROMO: Yes.ZINO: And I do think you know, to your point, Dagen -- Apple could kind of be smeared in terms of the China market there going forward and I think that's once again an opportunity for Huawei.And if you think about it here in the U.S., Huawei has no share. The U.S. doesn't allow Huawei to essentially kind of compete in this market. I think that could potentially be harmful in China at some point in time.BARTIROMO: Yes. They will do whatever they can. They'll use propaganda to make the point. Angelo -- it's great to have you.ZINO: All right. Thanks for having me.BARTIROMO: Angelo Zino joining us there.2020 Democrats facing off last night, sounding off in Detroit on the economy, jobs, trade.Hillary Vaughn was there for round two, part one of the Democratic debates. And some candidates on the stage with them last night said that they do think that progressive promises are not a winning strategy for 2020.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think if we're going to force Americans to make these radical changes, they're not going to go along. You can't just spring a plan on the world and expect it to succeed.SANDERS: Every credible poll that I have seen has me beating Donald Trump.UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Hillary Clinton was winning in the polls too. In this discussion already tonight, we've talked about taking private health insurance away from union members in the industrial Midwest. We've talked about decriminalizing the border. And we've talked about giving free healthcare to undocumented workers when so many Americans are struggling to pay for their healthcare.I quite frankly don't think that that is an agenda that we can move forward on and win.(END VIDEO CLIP)VAUGHN: One of those he progressive policies in the hot seat, Medicare for all. Former Congressman John Delaney has personal experience in the healthcare industry. He told Sanders that his plan for Medicare for all will not pay for itself because Sanders wants to eliminate private insurance. He says Medicare for all rates only cover 80 percent of the cost. Private insurance picks up the 20 percent remaining. So Delaney told Sanders last night the math just doesn't add up -- Maria.BARTIROMO: All right. Hillary -- thank you. Hillary Vaughn in Detroit this morning.Coming up, warning signs. New details emerging about the accused hacker behind the Capital One breach. Cloud security now front and center.Plus, the high cost of college, some parents go to the extreme making sure their kids' education bill gets paid. What they're doing -- wait until you hear this, next.BARTIROMO: Welcome back.We are learning more about the woman accused of hacking into more than 100 million credit card accounts at Capital One.Deirdre Bolton with the latest right now. Good morning -- Deirdre.DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Yes. Good morning -- Maria.So this person was struggling and I think we can tell that by her actions. I should keep saying "alleged" and the woman who has been charged with stealing 100 million people's data. But she's a transgender woman. She has been hopping from job to job -- former employers have described as somebody who was angry.She was actually tweeting out that she was going to check herself into a mental health facility a few weeks before she was arrested. On her Twitter account, which I will note has been suspended, she actually wrote something and said "I've basically strapped myself with a bomb vest, f-ing dropping Capital One's docs and admitting it to the point where another hacker on another platform said please don't go to jail over this."I think this happens with a lot of hackers. They're operating on the fringe but they still want credit somehow from the community for achieving something, and in this case it was stealing social security numbers and credit card numbers and dates of birth.And I think what this means for these companies, right, is to what extent are they willing to go more and more to the Cloud. Unfortunately, for Capital One, it was an early adopter five years ago, went to the Cloud. Most security experts are saying that while Amazon web services is at the heart of this particular issue, that it's not really at fault.For example, this young lady actually used an access point in the firewall. It wasn't really a problem technically with the Cloud. She accessed it another way. But just in the way that the story is developing, oddly enough she had worked for Amazon Cloud services for a number of years.But she's clearly mentally having a lot of battles. In fact, one thing that let the FBI find her home address was she had shared a vet bill. I guess her cat was sick, so it had her home address. It had her real name and that's one of the reasons that they were able to find her and arrest her.BARTIROMO: Wow -- incredible story.BLOCK: It really is. It just shows somebody very much on the fringe but who still wanted some sort of acceptance, if you like, from her peer group.But we know with Equifax, for example, which went through a similar hack, they just paid $700 million to settle a lawsuit, I should mention a class action lawsuit was filed yesterday in D.C., someone in Connecticut who has been affected has started to gather the troops.MURRAY: You know, Maria -- what is a little chilling in this case, a lot of hacks we think about them, we think of foreign agents or people overseas. It's a reminder that for big companies, you've got all kinds of vendors coming in and out, you've got all kinds of people doing different services on the web or on any other thing. And a really determined hacker who's got an inside track -- it's very, very hard to stop.BARTIROMO: Yes.MURRAY: It's very hard to do anything about that. And I think I think that's got to have a lot of companies looking at the situation closely and thinking again about their security protocols.BARTIROMO: You're right. We were saying that yesterday when the story first broke. We were thinking well, maybe it's China, maybe it's Russia. Oh, no, it's an American citizen, a woman. So scary stuff.Deirdre -- thanks.(CROSSTALKING)BOLTON: Sure. Thanks.BARTIROMO: We'll keep watching that.Coming up, all eyes on the Federal Reserve today, the central bank's crucial rate decision coming this afternoon. Fox Business will have complete coverage, live right here at 2:00. And we're expecting a quarter point cut.Back in a minute.BARTIROMO: Welcome back.Futures are higher this morning. We're at the highs of the morning right here. Of course, partly Apple. Dow futures up 71 points, quarter of a percent. The S&P futures up 5.75. And the Nasdaq futures up by 30 points right now.Investors are waiting on the fed this afternoon. The Federal Reserve expected to cut rates by a quarter point. We'll know at 2:15 p.m. Eastern. And we know we'll hear from Jay Powell as well.Joining us right now is the vice chairman and head of Investment Solutions Group at Bank of America, Keith Banks. Keith -- it's great to see you.KEITH BANKS, INVESTMENT SOLUTIONS GROUP HEAD, BANK OF AMERICA: Always good to be here -- Maria.BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining us.You're obviously expecting a cut as well, right.BANKS: We are.BARTIROMO: Yes. so what kind of impact is that going to have do you think, market reaction and impact on the economy?BANKS: Well, I think if we get to 25 basis points that I think the world now believes is going to be the outcome, that in and of itself shouldn't do a whole lot. I think the key is going to be what is the verbiage coming out? Do they talk about the -- you know, reinforce the possibility of further cuts, number one? Do they talk about maybe ending quantitative tightening a bit early -- this balance sheet runoff? That would be I think new news.But I think what the market wants to hear is that they're going to continue to look at the data and the data will dictate further action and most people believe further action that's required will in fact be additional cuts.BARTIROMO: I wonder if we're going to hear the winddown slowdown, $3.8 trillion now on the Federal Reserve balance sheet, they're supposed to get that all the down until like to close to $3 trillion or below $3 trillion. Is that something you're hearing as well, that maybe they come out with commentary on the balance sheet that they maybe stop the winding down?BANKS: I think it's one of the areas of speculation.BARTIROMO: Because that's in effect the tightening.BANKS: Yes.MURRAY: Keith -- can I ask, what problem do you think they're trying to solve? I'm asking because even though the market's priced it in, look, mortgage rates are coming down on their own, the economy is still doing pretty well. They didn't move last December when the market went haywire for a few weeks.Is it the right thing to cut rates? Should they keep cutting? What is the problem -- do you think there's a problem for them to solve?BANKS: I do think they should cut rates, number one. I do not think they're solving for the markets. I don't think they really care a whole lot about what the equity markets do unless maybe it begins to back up on consumer sentiment and business sentiment. But I think the real key is we've got -- we're now in the 11th year of the economic expansion and we've got inflation around 1.5 percent.When we go into the next downturn and there will be a next downturn, we don't think soon, that's not a lot of cushion. 150 basis points of inflation and zero and deflation is a pretty tight, you know, pretty tight fan there.BARTIROMO: Especially while the rest of the world is cutting and stimulating.BANKS: Especially while the rest of the world is cutting, especially while the rest of the world is slowing. So I think what they're trying to do is get the economy to run hotter. See if we can get a more reflationary environment. And also, you know, ensure that we've got, you know, as healthy an environment as possible when we do enter the next downturn which we don't think will be for at least a couple of years. But it will happen.BARTIROMO: Wow.BELL: But to get inflation going -- 25 basis points, do you really think that's going to do it or are you saying that there's going to be multiple cuts in the remainder of year and into 2020? What are your expectations?BANKS: You're right. 25 basis points in and of itself is not going to -- it's not the magic wand that's going to suddenly change everything.BARTIROMO: No, but he market expects like three cuts.BANKS: Yes. But I think the market expects three cuts. Our hope is that as you begin to see in the second half a pickup in foreign activity, we've seen a lot of stimulus coming out of China, we do think that will begin to show itself.You've got at last count at least 15 central banks are in easing mode. We'll probably see something in September out of Europe, maybe a quantitative easing 2 out of Europe. I don't know how much you can --BARTIROMO: What are they going to do? I mean because they're at negative rates, right?BANKS: Yes. I mean lower rates, going from negative 41 basis points on the 10-year boom in Germany to negative 51 is not going to probably do a whole lot.BARTIROMO: Right.BANKS: But, you know, it's got to be something more creative in terms of, you know, buying back bonds or something else --BARTIROMO: Or buying stocks.BANKS: -- or buying stocks. You mentioned Rick has said that last week because they've got to get more creative. It's not just about lowering rates. I think all the above is important.MCDOWELL: How about structural reform in Europe?BANKS: Structural reform would be wonderful.MCDOWELL: Yes, labor reform.BANKS: That would be -- I'm not sure we can count on that -- Dagen. But that would be --(CROSSTALKING)MURRAY: What about Brexit? We're seeing -- we're really seeing the pound take a beating this week. Is that going to matter at all here in the fall?BANKS: Well, I think Brexit is one of a number of things that matter. And it's part of -- I think when the -- even the fed thinks about the U.S. and our rates, they're looking at a global picture because our U.S. companies are so global, especially in the S&P 500, foreign activity matters. I think over almost 32 percent of S&P 500 earnings now come from foreign profits.BARTIROMO: It's a big number.BANKS: So the Fed is looking at this big mosaic of information that I think is driving them toward the action we hope they're going to take today which would be the beginning of multiple steps.BARTIROMO: We've got the Eurozone GDP out, second quarter was in line. Taiwan was better in the second quarter. How would you characterize the global economy right now.BANKS: Well, you know, it's interesting. We're on a dual track. Our research team wrote a report called "The Great Divide" because you're got the U.S., which is being powered by the consumer, small business, housing, things of that nature, all of which are strong or in good shape -- at least small business and consumer. And the rest of the world is more dependent on trade and manufacturing which is the sweet spot of weakness.And so what's been ironic is that the tightening we did in the U.S. in 2018 and the trade war we've been undertaking with China has had a bigger impact and a much more negative impact on the rest of the world.So, you know, we're kind of pulling away from the rest of the world as far as growth which is one of the reasons why we like the U.S. market better than we like the international developed markets because we just think that's going to continue. We're going to grow we believe at or above trend in the U.S. And the rest of the world is going to struggle to grow at trend, more likely for a while below trend.BARTIROMO: I love what you said earlier, that you think that this is going to be another couple years of this economic expansion. Now, here we are in year 11. So that's a good backdrop for stocks.BANKS: Well, it's interesting. There's -- the excesses aren't building, right. Inflation is low, going lower, rates are going lower, consumer sentiment is strong. None of the things that typically tip over the economy -- old age doesn't do. Old age tips us over, it doesn't tip markets over. People have to remember that. That's what we got to keep an eye on.(CROSSTALKING)BARTIROMO: You like the market.BANKS: Yes.BARTIROMO: Keith -- it's good to see you.BANKS: Good to be here.BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Keith Banks joining us there, Bank of America.We will have special coverage here on Fox Business of the Federal Reserve decision today at 2:00 p.m. Eastern. Join us. We've got all hands on deck this afternoon.Coming up, the Dems in Detroit -- 2020 candidates going head to head last night debating winners, losers and what to expect in round two tonight.And then paying for college, the tricks some parents are playing to get more financial aid. Wait until you hear this. Is it moral? We've got that debate coming up.Stay with us.BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Wednesday, July 31st. Your stop stories right now, 7:32 a.m. on the East Coast.Investors across the world keeping a close eye on the Federal Reserve today and the decision on interest rates along with a string of earnings for the second quarter.Markets are higher, we're at the highs of the morning right here, markets getting a big push from Apple with the Dow Jones Futures up 74 points, quarter of a percent, the S&P Futures up six and the NASDAQ Futures higher by 30 points.General Electric out with a double beat and it is also raising its profit outlook as you see, G.E. shares were up 4-1/2 percent. Humana seeing a jump in revenue, raising its full year guidance as well. Humana share up 2-3/4 percent.Yesterday, stocks slipped after President Trump said that China trade talks are basically slow and saying that China does not come through on its agreements. It -- he warned China not to wait for the 2020 election to do a deal. He says it will be tougher then.Global markets this morning are lower -- well, that was yesterday's trade. As you can see, the Dow yesterday was down 23 and the S&P was down seven. The NASDAQ was lower by 19 points.Global markets this morning are mixed. Take a look at European indices where the consumer is strong in Germany apparently, retail sales posted the biggest monthly jump in Germany since December 06 and the DAX Index is up 27 points, quarter of a percent. The FT-100 in London is down 50 points and the CAC Quarante in Paris is up five.In Asia overnight, declines across the board. There is also more signs of slowdown in China. Factory activity contracting for the third month in a row in China.The showdown in Motor City, Democrats going head to head on the economy, healthcare and immigration. Giving up guardianship of their kids.Plus this, valuable life lessons from Monopoly. The hilarious video that captures a young boy feeling the pain of taxes. Yes, we feel your pain.All those stories coming up this Wednesday morning, but first, our top story this half an hour, the Democratic debate. 10 2020 candidates going head-to-head last night during night one of a second set ready to face-off tonight, watch.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)GOV. Juan, great to see you.JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST: Good morning.BARTIROMO: How was the debate from your standpoint?WILLIAMS: I think wait as success for the Democrats overall because I thought it was a real debate about real issues and what you were able to see is the moderate wing of the party versus the more liberal progressive wing of the party versus the more liberal progressive wing of the party. And what happened there I think was not only illuminating if you were watching but you saw for example the debate about Medicare for All play out in a way that I thought people could understand, appreciate and decide who they wanted to back.But the bigger point is I think that Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders who going into this were positive as potentially fighting each other for the left lane of the party. You don't --WILLIAMS: Correct, I don't think it worked for Hickenlooper at all.BARTIROMO: OK.MATT MURRAY, EDITOR IN CHIEF, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Well, Juan, how worried do you think Democrats are getting about electability? Because it was striking. In the first set of debates it was sort of a march to the left. Everybody topping each other. Here you had very clear lines with moderates really kind of arguing we're not going to beat the president with these policies and Warren and Sanders as you say, kind of allied and going further and farther.How much concern does that reflect in the Democratic Party right now about how the race is going and about the chances of beating the president?WILLIAMS: I think that there's a pretty strong sense that you can beat the president but the argument is do you do this with a vision that? We can do better for the working people in this country. We can do better in terms of healthcare where so many people don't have coverage or being bankrupted. We can do better in terms of helping our kids who are burdened by high school tuition debt.BELL: Well, I have a question. Cardi B has come out kind of as a wild card. And then you, you know, turn in the morning shows or the morning paper, Matt's morning Wall Street Journal.But now, Cardi B does something with Bernie Sanders, it gets 2.5 million people to pick it up. You think --BARTIROMO: That's unbelievable.WILLIAMS: -- wait a minute, who are these people and do they vote and do they give money? I don't know the answers yet. She --BARTIROMO: Yes, I had forgotten that. You're right. That was a good moment.MCDOWELL: And it was -- but it was -- she's very, very smart and very savvy and she came at it from that.But I want to ask you, though, ultimately Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren have to justify taking private health insurance away from 180 million people and they have to convince people that the government and bureaucrats somehow are going to deliver better health coverage than private companies. And I think that that is a long, long way to go on that.WILLIAMS: I think they did very well on just that point last night when they pointed out that -- and Bernie said this explicitly, you're going to have to pay less in terms of deductibles, less in terms of coverage. And it will compensate --BARTIROMO: Yes, but it blow off the question about raising taxes on the middle class (INAUDIBLE).WILLIAMS: No, because it said that in fact, you would benefit more. The average American middles class family is going to benefit more from Medicaid for All than from the current tax structure.No, and in respond to your point, --MCDOWELL: But he didn't have --WILLIAMS: -- that's what the private insurers that are there now are the ones that as Bernie says are ripping off people, making huge profits whilst large numbers of people go uncovered or inadequately covered.MCDOWELL: Juan, they need to explain to people how they're going to deliver this when Medicare as we know it is going broke. The Medicare hospital trust fund goes broke in less than seven years, in 2026. People benefits will immediately get cut to $0.89 on the dollar, danger.He's not in favor of fixing that. He wants to rip the entire thing up. And ultimately it's going to wind up with price controls and rationing. And if you have anything else wrong with you other than an ear infection and need antibiotic, you are going to have to wait months for coverage. And it's --WILLIAMS: That's a -- that's scare language. That's kind of fear mongering.MCDOWELL: No it's not, it's a fact.WILLIAMS: Because what Bernie said in response to your point would be, you need structural change. And this comes back to what Matt and I were talking about at the time. If you believe in a vision beyond the status quo, will that sell to voters or you just -- do you simply have to say, boy, this Donald Trump guy is kind of off the rail.MCDOWELL: When government was in charge of people's healthcare, you had individuals in this country who were mentally disabled being sterilized by states across the country. That only --WILLIAMS: How is that relevant to this (INAUDIBLE)?MCDOWELL: Because you know what, when the government takes over healthcare, that's what happens. It was 1979 is when it ended.BARTIROMO: It's about government wanting your healthcare. And the government putting in a major, big federal program and doing away with 180 million people's healthcare plans --(CROSSTALK)WILLIAMS: I'm talking to now small government conservatives, the two of you.BARTIROMO: That's right.WILLIAMS: And I guess you back to Donald Trump's budget which is that big government big standing budget.BARTIROMO: No, that has nothing to do with this conversation.WILLIAMS: Well, I'm just saying, there's some kind of hypocrisy on among the right --MCDOWELL: No, you need to watch her show.BARTIROMO: You need to watch this program.WILLIAMS: Because there's hypocrisy --BARTIROMO: I (INAUDIBLE) big federal programs every day and how they're bad.WILLIAMS: Right, so you know what, who --BARTIROMO: Look at the Post Office.WILLIAMS: What happened here, Mitch McConnell, the Republicans, they backed this budget, didn't they? Big spending, big deficits.BARTIROMO: Well, the Dems -- the Dems wanted all that discretionary spending.WILLIAMS: Oh, yes. And Donald Trump did what?BARTIROMO: They won't allow the Republicans to protect the military so that they can have --WILLIAMS: What did Maria do on -- Maria, what did Donald Trump do on taxes? He raised taxes that benefited the rich in this country and took away revenue.BARTIROMO: Every income level went down in terms of taxes, Juan, you know this and they doubled the standard deduction. Every single income went down.WILLIAMS: Overwhelming, I think it's like 25 percent of the benefit of that tax cut went to the one percent and you're saying, oh, we can't afford to help out people who need help here.BARTIROMO: And last -- and last year we got a quarter -- and last year we got a quarter better than four percent growth.WILLIAMS: Yes.BARTIROMO: And this year we got 3.1 percent growth in the first quarter and 3.1 percent growth in the second quarter.WILLIAMS: Oh, my guys, (INAUDIBLE). I think we can afford to help people if we --BARTIROMO: The tax cut legislation has moved the needle on economic growth, Juan. You have to admit that.WILLIAMS: It hasn't moved a needle. We are talking about healthcare. We're talking about education. We're talking about a vision for America and you guys say, oh, we can't afford it, but we can give tax cuts to the rich. Oh, we can do this.BARTIROMO: Should we go back to the under two percent growth under Barack Obama for eight years?WILLIAMS: How about consistent growth that right now is setting records and has the stock market at (INAUDIBLE).BARTIROMO: Sounds like we got it -- sounds like we got it.WILLIAMS: Yes, and we can -- it as an affluent society afford to help people.BARTIROMO: Well, deregulation, a little tax cuts. You get some economic growth from there, wow.WILLIAMS: Let's have an election -- let's have an election.BARTIROMO: Look how that happens.MCDOWELL: Wages are growing faster than we even expected. Thank you, Obama, thank you.BARTIROMO: Oh, come on, Juan.WILLIAMS: That's the fact.MCDOWELL: And by the way --BARTIROMO: It's not a fact at all. Come on.WILLIAMS: It's doing so great, the Fed -- the Fed doesn't have to raise anything today, it doesn't have to help us. No, no, no, things are just going great.BARTIROMO: Juan, thank you. We'll be right back.BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A little boy learning a big life lesson. Courtesy of the game Monopoly. Making sure the tuition bill gets paid. Why it's sparking a morality debate around that. Next up, stay with us.BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The high cost of college, the Wall Street Journal highlighting an option some parents are using, bending the rules to get that tuition bill paid up, giving up custody of their kids to get more financial aid.Joining us right now, University of Maryland professor Emeritus and columnist Peter Morici. And it's great to see you, Peter. Thank you so much for being here.PETER MORICI, PROFESSOR EMERITUS, UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND: Nice to be with you.BARTIROMO: Well, this is pretty extreme.MORICI: Oh, absolutely. But it's not novel. I mean, going back to the 60s when I was a kid in school, there were people who would try to become financially independent of their parents or at least claim independence to max their financial aid. This is a different wrinkle, you sign over custody to a poorer relative.I think we need to say that this is wrong but also to look at it in the context of the recent admissions scandal and ask why are parents going to such extremes? And I think the answer is the way colleges and universities treat them. Frankly, very cynically.They do a lot of differential pricing. They do a lot of price gouging. They have bloated bureaucracies. They're terribly high cost operations. You know, I often think the healthcare mess has a purpose, it's to keep the spotlight off of people like me.BARTIROMO: Yes, well, you make a good point in terms of what colleges are doing to encourage this. Matt, talk about the story in the Journal in terms of what's being done out there.MURRAY: So, it was a story that really came out of Illinois where we noticed that there were a spike in guardianship requests and tracked down the colleges. It's got the University of Illinois very concerned. We talked to the admission folks there.This is a new tactic, in the suburbs of Chicago. And it's -- a lot of these families who, you know, their income is good, would put them fairly high but the cost of college is so high, they've got three or four kids that some of them are deploying this tactic.There's actually supposed to be a college counselor out there in Illinois who's advising people that this is a smart strategy to use.BARTIROMO: OK.MURRAY: So the idea's gotten out there. And you know, I think -- I think what Peter said is interesting, because navigating college for your kid is one of the most complicated, gut-wrenching, challenging things for any family, wealthy or not.Although, it is true that wealthy people are learning the game the system pretty aggressively for their kids in a way that seems very unfair to others, especially because these programs are really there to help kids who can't afford college.BARTIROMO: Yes, as Peter, you just said, it's not right.Meanwhile, Peter -- billionaire tech investor Peter Thiel joined Tucker Carlson last night with a different take on elite institutions and their tax exempt status. Listen to what he said.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)PETER THIEL, CO-FOUNDER, PAYPAL: If the elite colleges were educating people, if Harvard or Stanford were educating people, and giving them a great education, they should be just doubling or tripling the enrollment. And what sort of business is doing something great for its customers and doesn't increase the number of its customers. That's a really weird business.But the closest analogy in business I can come up with is that it's something like the Studio 54 Nightclub. You have an incredibly long line outside, only a few people get in and the value comes from being exclusionary. They're not inclusive, they're exclusionary, and that's where the value comes from.TUCKER CARLSON, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST: And a highly self-satisfied bouncer.THIEL: And then if you think of it as the Stanford or Yale or Harvard, Studio 54 Nightclub that you're running, it's perhaps good for the prestige and status of the students. Maybe it's bad for their morals but it certainly doesn't deserve a tax exemption.(END VIDEO CLIP)BARTIROMO: Peter, your thoughts. Obviously you know, you're making choices there and a lot of people are getting hurt.MORICI: Well, the reality is that you talk about university enrolment, most universities don't want to have really huge undergraduate enrolments. The state university like the one I taught at has to have a large undergraduate enrolment. That's our mandate.But a place like Harvard or Cornell or Columbia or what have you, the Ivies, Northwestern and so forth.BARTIROMO: Right.MORICI: They have to -- they see themselves more as research institutions, with large endowments that can devote themselves to PhD students and granting MBAs and things of that nature. Many of those activities MBAs being an exception are not particularly profitable but their endowments provide for it.BARTIROMO: Right.MORICI: They're not particularly interested in having, you know, 20,000 undergraduates at Harvard.BARTIROMO: Yes, they want to be exclusionary, exactly. Peter, its good --MORICI: Well, it's not only that. It's what they want to do with their faculty.BARTIROMO: Right. Peter, it's good to see you. Thank you so much. Peter Morici, joining us there.Stay with us, we've got the ADP number coming out and then U.S.-China trade talks. Back in a minute.Load-Date: July 31, 2019End of Document

Dec: 1334Moving the MarketSector WatchStock market little changed following yesterday's sell-offWalmart (WMT) earnings and guidance, July retail sales reflect that the U.S. consumer is still in good shapeChina threaten countermeasures to U.S. tariffs but hopes U.S. can meet halfway in trade talksStrong: Consumer Staples, FinancialsWeak: Energy, Industrials, Information Technology10:55 ETDow +66.58 at 25545.98, Nasdaq +13.34 at 7787.29, S&P +11.44 at 2852.04[BRIEFING.COM] The market has been clinging onto modest gains today, although the price action has not been very convincing. The S&P 500 is up 0.4%.Overnight, the futures market was signaling more losses at the open after China vowed countermeasures against the 10% tariff rate that is set to go into effect Sept. 1. China did soften its stance later, saying it hopes the U.S. can meet halfway in trade talks but this is a line it has been saying for quite some time now.In other earnings news, Tapestry (TPR 20.30, -4.70, -18.8%) shares have plunged nearly 20% after the company missed revenue estimates and provided disappointing guidance for the upcoming quarter and the rest of its fiscal year.10:25 ETDow +66.28 at 25545.68, Nasdaq +19.73 at 7793.68, S&P +12.09 at 2852.69[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades higher by 0.5%.Dow components Walmart (WMT 111.14, +4.94, +4.7%) and Cisco Systems (CSCO 47.32, -3.30, -6.5%) have been in focus today after releasing their earnings reports. Walmart provided solid quarterly results and raised its full-year EPS guidance, while Cisco Systems guided its fiscal Q1 EPS and revenue below consensus.General Electric (GE 8.42, -0.61, -6.8%) has also received plenty of attention today, with shares down nearly 7% after whistleblower Harry Markopolos labeled GE a "Bigger Fraud Than Enron" in a critical report on GE's accounting.10:00 ETDow +78.14 at 25557.54, Nasdaq +13.54 at 7787.49, S&P +9.58 at 2850.18[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is up 0.4%, while the Russell 2000 is down 0.1%.Business inventories were unchanged in June (Briefing.com consensus 0.1%). The May reading was unrevised at 0.3%.Earlier, industrial production for July declined 0.2% (Briefing.com consensus 0.1%) following an revised increase of 0.2% in June (from 0.0%). Capacity utilization decreased to 77.5% in July (Briefing.com consensus 77.8%) from 77.8% in June (revised from 77.9%).09:45 ETDow -39.74 at 25439.66, Nasdaq -28.99 at 7744.96, S&P -5.45 at 2835.15[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages begin the day slightly lower after their worst performance of the year yesterday. The S&P 500 is down 0.1%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.1%, and the Nasdaq Composite is down 0.2%.Looking at the S&P 500 sector standings shows consumer staples (+0.7%) and financials (+0.6%) providing some support for the broader market. Conversely, the energy (-0.8%), industrials (-0.6%), and information technology (-0.5%) sectors have been influential laggards.U.S. Treasuries have edged higher, pushing yields lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield is down three basis points to 1.55%, and the 10-yr yield is down one basis point to 1.57%. The U.S. Dollar Index is unchanged at 97.99. WTI crude is down 1.6% to $54.34/bbl.09:13 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +18.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +43.80.The stock market is on pace to open higher following positive results and guidance from Walmart (WMT 113.24, +7.04, +6.6%) and encouraging economic data. The S&P 500 futures trade 18 points, or 0.6%, above fair value in a volatile pre-market session.Walmart's impressive results and confidence, coupled with a 0.7% increase in July retail sales (Briefing.com consensus 0.3%), has reassured the market that the U.S. consumer is still in good shape. More so, it has helped the market overlook possible Chinese retaliation against the upcoming tariffs and underwhelming guidance from Cisco Systems (CSCO 47.53, -3.08, -6.1%).To be fair, China followed up and said it hopes the U.S. can meet halfway in trade talks. USTR Lighthizer, however, reportedly told China that it "wouldn't be possible" to meet "halfway," according to CNBC.U.S. Treasuries have come down from prior highs, bringing yields near their unchanged marks. The 2-yr yield is down one basis point to 1.57%, and the 10-yr yield is unchanged at 1.58%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.94.08:50 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +16.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +39.30.The S&P 500 futures trade 16 points, or 0.6%, above fair value.Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended Thursday on a mixed note. The People's Bank of China fixed the yuan at a slightly higher level for the second day in a row. South China Morning Post quoted a Chinese government adviser as saying that protest in Hong Kong do not warrant direct intervention yet due to a high risk of damaging international relations. Australia reported better than expected employment figures for July, but expectations for more rate cuts remain in place.In economic data: China's July House Prices +9.7% yr/yr (last 10.3%) Japan's June Industrial Production -3.3% m/m (expected -3.6%; last -3.6%) and Capacity Utilization -2.6% m/m (expected 0.2%; last 1.7%) Australia's July Employment Change 41,100 (expected 14,000; last 500) and Full Employment Change 34,500 (last 21,100). Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +13.90.The S&P 500 futures trade 13 points, or 0.5%, above fair value.July retail sales increased 0.7% (Briefing.com consensus +0.3%), while the June reading was revised down to 0.3% from 0.4%. Excluding autos, retail sales increased 1.0% in July (Briefing.com consensus +0.3%), and the June reading was also revised down to 0.3% from 0.4%.The latest weekly initial jobless claims count totaled 220,000, while Briefing.com consensus expected a total of 215,000. Today's tally was above the prior week's revised count of 211,00 (from 209,000). As for continuing claims, they increased to 1.726 million from a revised count of 1.687 million (from 1.684 million).The preliminary unit labor costs increased 2.4% during the second quarter, while the Briefing.com consensus expected an increase of 1.6%. The preliminary productivity reading showed an increase of 2.3%, while the Briefing.com consensus expected an increase of 1.3%.The Empire State Manufacturing Survey for August increased to 4.8 (Briefing.com consensus 1.1) from the prior month's reading of 4.3.The Philadelphia Fed Index for August came in at 16.8 (Briefing.com consensus 10.0), below the 21.8 reading in July.07:55 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +14.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +23.30.The S&P 500 futures trade 15 points, or 0.5%, above fair value in a volatile pre-market session. Futures were pulled lower after China threatened to retaliate against the upcoming 10% tariff rate on Chinese imports, but solid results and guidance from Walmart (WMT 112.71, +6.51, +6.1%) has lifted futures back into positive territory.The market is presumably trying to find its footing after a sharp 3% sell-off yesterday that was attributed to recessionary fears. China added to those worries this morning, but it didn't provide any specific details related to countermeasures. Instead, Walmart has given the market some reassurance that consumer spending remains resilient, which has outweighed the disappointing guidance from Cisco Systems (CSCO 46.38, -4.23, -8.4%).A wide range of economic data will be released today, which will feature Retail Sales for July (Briefing.com consensus 0.3%) at 8:30 a.m. ET.The weekly Initial Claims (Briefing.com consensus 215,000) and Continuing Claims report, the Empire State Manufacturing Index for August (Briefing.com consensus 1.1), the Philadelphia Fed Index for August (Briefing.com consensus 10.0), and the preliminary Q2 readings for Productivity (Briefing.com consensus 1.3%) and Unit Labor Costs (Briefing.com consensus 1.6%) will also be released at 8:30 a.m. ET.In addition, Industrial Production (Briefing.com consensus 0.1%) and Capacity Utilization (Briefing.com consensus 77.8%) for July will be released at 9:15 a.m. ET, followed by Business Inventories for June (Briefing.com consensus 0.1%) at 10:00 a.m. ET and Net Long-Term TIC Flows for June at 4:00 p.m. ET.The U.S. Treasury market continues to see increased demand, driving yields even lower across the curve. Currently, the 2-yr yield is down five basis points to 1.53% and the 10-yr yield is down four basis points to 1.54%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.88. WTI crude is down 1.1% to $54.61/bbl.In U.S. Corporate news:Cisco Systems (CSCO 46.38, -4.23): -8.4% after guiding Q1 EPS and revenue below consensus. Its earnings results came in better than expected. Walmart (WMT 112.71, +6.51): +6.1% after beating earnings and comparable sales estimates and raising its full-year EPS guidance. General Electric (GE 8.68, -0.33): -3.7% after Bernie Madoff whistleblower Harry Markopolos issued a critical report on GE's accounting.Tapestry (TPR 23.51, -1.49): -6.0% after missing revenue estimates and issuing disappointing guidance.Reviewing overnight developments:Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended Thursday on a mixed note. Shares of Deutsche Bank are on the verge of falling to a fresh record low in Frankfurt.07:28 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -5.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -52.00.07:03 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -10.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -68.80.07:03 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] Nikkei...20406...-249.50...-1.20%. Hang Seng...25495.5...+193.20...+0.80%.07:03 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] FTSE...7029.31...-118.60...-1.70%. DAX...11291.73...-200.90...-1.80%.16:20 ETDow -800.49 at 25479.40, Nasdaq -242.42 at 7773.95, S&P -85.72 at 2840.6[BRIEFING.COM] Each of the major U.S. indices lost around 3.0% on Wednesday, as weak global data and a recessionary signal in the U.S. Treasury market sent stocks reeling. Broad-based selling left both S&P 500 and Russell 2000 down 2.9%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 3.1%, and the Nasdaq Composite lost 3.0%.The stock market began the day sharply lower, giving back a bulk of yesterday's advance, after data out of China and Germany continued to weaken. China reported its slowest industrial production growth since 2002, and Germany reported a 0.1% qtr/qtr decline in Q2 GDP. Understandably, investors rushed to safe-haven assets such as gold ($1527.80, +$13.70, +0.9%) and U.S. Treasuries, while equities steadily declined throughout the day.In turn, the yield on the 10-yr note fell below the yield on the 2-yr note for the first time since 2007, representing an inversion that has preceded each recession since 1980. The average length of time between the first inversion and the start of each recession since 1980 has averaged 18 months, with the range being as little as ten months to as many as two years.Despite this historical time-cushion, it was risk-off on Wall Street with all 11 S&P 500 sectors finishing lower. The energy (-4.1%) and financials (-3.6%) sectors led the broader retreat amid steep declines in oil prices ($55.01/bbl, -$2.03, -3.6%) and U.S. Treasury yields. The utilities sector (-0.9%) was the only sector that didn't finish lower by at least 1.0%.The 2-yr yield fell nine basis points to 1.58%, and the 10-yr yield fell ten basis points to 1.58%. Interestingly, the 30-yr yield hit a record low at 2.02% before finishing the session down 11 basis points at 2.03%. The U.S. Dollar Index held firm, advancing 0.2% to 98.04.It should be noted that the 2s-10s yield spread did not remain inverted during the session. Still, the yield curve had been steadily flattening all year and investors weren't given any reason today to expect a change of course. The yield-curve flattening undercut shares of Citigroup (C 61.41, -3.42, -5.3%), Bank of America (BAC 26.42, -1.30, -4.7%), and JPMorgan Chase (JPM 104.80, -4.54, -4.2%).Separately, Macy's (M 16.80, -2.56, -13.2%) provided disappointing earnings and guidance, which sent shares down 13.2% and put additional pressure on the SPDR S&P Retail ETF (XRT 38.42, -1.68, -4.2%).Reviewing Wednesday's economic data, which included Import and Export Prices for July and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index:Import prices rose 0.2% m/m in July, but declined 0.1% excluding fuel. On a yr/yr basis, all import prices were down 1.8%, versus up 4.8% for the 12 months ending in July 2018, while nonfuel import prices declined 1.3% versus a 1.4% increase for the 12 months ending in July 2018.Export prices were up 0.2% m/m in July. Excluding agricultural exports, prices were also up 0.2%. On a yr/yr basis, all export prices were down 0.9%, versus up 4.3% for the 12 months ending in July 2018, while nonagricultural export prices were down 1.5%, versus up 5.0% for the 12 months ending in July 2018.The key takeaway from the report is that it doesn't show any inflation, which stands in contrast to the Consumer Price Index for July. Accordingly, it will only serve to confuse the market's perspective on the Fed's read of inflation trends.The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index spiked 21.7% following a 5.3% increase in the prior week.Investors will receive the following economic data on Thursday: Retail Sales for July, Industrial Production and Capacity Utilization for July, the Empire State Manufacturing Survey for August, the Philadelphia Fed Index for August, the weekly Initial and Continuing Claims report, the preliminary Productivity and Unit Labor Costs for the second quarter, Business Inventories for June, and Net Long-Term TIC Flows for June.Briefing.com is the leading Internet provider of live market analysis for U.S. Stock, U.S. Bond and world FX market participants. 1-800-752-3013 or http://www.briefing.comLoad-Date: August 15, 2019End of Document

China added to those worries this morning, but it didn't provide any specific details related to countermeasures. Instead, Walmart has given the market some reassurance that consumer spending remains resilient, which has outweighed the disappointing guidance from Cisco Systems (CSCO 46.38, -4.23, -8.4%).A wide range of economic data will be released today, which will feature Retail Sales for July (Briefing.com consensus 0.3%) at 8:30 a.m. ET.The weekly Initial Claims (Briefing.com consensus 215,000) and Continuing Claims report, the Empire State Manufacturing Index for August (Briefing.com consensus 1.1), the Philadelphia Fed Index for August (Briefing.com consensus 10.0), and the preliminary Q2 readings for Productivity (Briefing.com consensus 1.3%) and Unit Labor Costs (Briefing.com consensus 1.6%) will also be released at 8:30 a.m. ET.In addition, Industrial Production (Briefing.com consensus 0.1%) and Capacity Utilization (Briefing.com consensus 77.8%) for July will be released at 9:15 a.m. ET, followed by Business Inventories for June (Briefing.com consensus 0.1%) at 10:00 a.m. ET and Net Long-Term TIC Flows for June at 4:00 p.m. ET.The U.S. Treasury market continues to see increased demand, driving yields even lower across the curve. Currently, the 2-yr yield is down five basis points to 1.53% and the 10-yr yield is down four basis points to 1.54%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.88. WTI crude is down 1.1% to $54.61/bbl.In U.S. Corporate news:Cisco Systems (CSCO 46.38, -4.23): -8.4% after guiding Q1 EPS and revenue below consensus. Its earnings results came in better than expected. Walmart (WMT 112.71, +6.51): +6.1% after beating earnings and comparable sales estimates and raising its full-year EPS guidance. General Electric (GE 8.68, -0.33): -3.7% after Bernie Madoff whistleblower Harry Markopolos issued a critical report on GE's accounting.Tapestry (TPR 23.51, -1.49): -6.0% after missing revenue estimates and issuing disappointing guidance.Reviewing overnight developments:Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended Thursday on a mixed note. Shares of Deutsche Bank are on the verge of falling to a fresh record low in Frankfurt.07:28 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -5.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -52.00.07:03 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -10.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -68.80.07:03 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] Nikkei...20406...-249.50...-1.20%. Hang Seng...25495.5...+193.20...+0.80%.07:03 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] FTSE...7029.31...-118.60...-1.70%. DAX...11291.73...-200.90...-1.80%.16:20 ETDow -800.49 at 25479.40, Nasdaq -242.42 at 7773.95, S&P -85.72 at 2840.6[BRIEFING.COM] Each of the major U.S. indices lost around 3.0% on Wednesday, as weak global data and a recessionary signal in the U.S. Treasury market sent stocks reeling. Broad-based selling left both S&P 500 and Russell 2000 down 2.9%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 3.1%, and the Nasdaq Composite lost 3.0%.The stock market began the day sharply lower, giving back a bulk of yesterday's advance, after data out of China and Germany continued to weaken. China reported its slowest industrial production growth since 2002, and Germany reported a 0.1% qtr/qtr decline in Q2 GDP. Understandably, investors rushed to safe-haven assets such as gold ($1527.80, +$13.70, +0.9%) and U.S. Treasuries, while equities steadily declined throughout the day.In turn, the yield on the 10-yr note fell below the yield on the 2-yr note for the first time since 2007, representing an inversion that has preceded each recession since 1980. The average length of time between the first inversion and the start of each recession since 1980 has averaged 18 months, with the range being as little as ten months to as many as two years.Despite this historical time-cushion, it was risk-off on Wall Street with all 11 S&P 500 sectors finishing lower. The energy (-4.1%) and financials (-3.6%) sectors led the broader retreat amid steep declines in oil prices ($55.01/bbl, -$2.03, -3.6%) and U.S. Treasury yields. The utilities sector (-0.9%) was the only sector that didn't finish lower by at least 1.0%.The 2-yr yield fell nine basis points to 1.58%, and the 10-yr yield fell ten basis points to 1.58%. Interestingly, the 30-yr yield hit a record low at 2.02% before finishing the session down 11 basis points at 2.03%. The U.S. Dollar Index held firm, advancing 0.2% to 98.04.It should be noted that the 2s-10s yield spread did not remain inverted during the session. Still, the yield curve had been steadily flattening all year and investors weren't given any reason today to expect a change of course. The yield-curve flattening undercut shares of Citigroup (C 61.41, -3.42, -5.3%), Bank of America (BAC 26.42, -1.30, -4.7%), and JPMorgan Chase (JPM 104.80, -4.54, -4.2%).Separately, Macy's (M 16.80, -2.56, -13.2%) provided disappointing earnings and guidance, which sent shares down 13.2% and put additional pressure on the SPDR S&P Retail ETF (XRT 38.42, -1.68, -4.2%).Reviewing Wednesday's economic data, which included Import and Export Prices for July and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index:Import prices rose 0.2% m/m in July, but declined 0.1% excluding fuel. On a yr/yr basis, all import prices were down 1.8%, versus up 4.8% for the 12 months ending in July 2018, while nonfuel import prices declined 1.3% versus a 1.4% increase for the 12 months ending in July 2018.Export prices were up 0.2% m/m in July. Excluding agricultural exports, prices were also up 0.2%. On a yr/yr basis, all export prices were down 0.9%, versus up 4.3% for the 12 months ending in July 2018, while nonagricultural export prices were down 1.5%, versus up 5.0% for the 12 months ending in July 2018.The key takeaway from the report is that it doesn't show any inflation, which stands in contrast to the Consumer Price Index for July. Accordingly, it will only serve to confuse the market's perspective on the Fed's read of inflation trends.The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index spiked 21.7% following a 5.3% increase in the prior week.Investors will receive the following economic data on Thursday: Retail Sales for July, Industrial Production and Capacity Utilization for July, the Empire State Manufacturing Survey for August, the Philadelphia Fed Index for August, the weekly Initial and Continuing Claims report, the preliminary Productivity and Unit Labor Costs for the second quarter, Business Inventories for June, and Net Long-Term TIC Flows for June.Briefing.com is the leading Internet provider of live market analysis for U.S. Stock, U.S. Bond and world FX market participants. 1-800-752-3013 or http://www.briefing.comLoad-Date: August 15, 2019End of Document

Energy stocks remain under pressure as oil prices continue to retreat, while the industrials sector has been weighed down by a x% drop in shares of General Electric (-x%). GE has nearly doubled its losses since the last update.The tech sector has been dragged lower by shares of Apple (AAPL 200.74, -1.97, -1.0%), Microsoft (MFST 132.79, -1.18, -0.9%), and Cisco Systems (CSCO 46.86, -3.75, -7.4%) -- the latter of which remains noticeably lower following its disappointing guidance.10:55 ETDow +66.58 at 25545.98, Nasdaq +13.34 at 7787.29, S&P +11.44 at 2852.04[BRIEFING.COM] The market has been clinging onto modest gains today, although the price action has not been very convincing. China did soften its stance later, saying it hopes the U.S. can meet halfway in trade talks but this is a line it has been saying for quite some time now.In other earnings news, Tapestry (TPR 20.30, -4.70, -18.8%) shares have plunged nearly 20% after the company missed revenue estimates and provided disappointing guidance for the upcoming quarter and the rest of its fiscal year.10:25 ETDow +66.28 at 25545.68, Nasdaq +19.73 at 7793.68, S&P +12.09 at 2852.69[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades higher by 0.5%.Dow components Walmart (WMT 111.14, +4.94, +4.7%) and Cisco Systems (CSCO 47.32, -3.30, -6.5%) have been in focus today after releasing their earnings reports. Walmart provided solid quarterly results and raised its full-year EPS guidance, while Cisco Systems guided its fiscal Q1 EPS and revenue below consensus.General Electric (GE 8.42, -0.61, -6.8%) has also received plenty of attention today, with shares down nearly 7% after whistleblower Harry Markopolos labeled GE a "Bigger Fraud Than Enron" in a critical report on GE's accounting.10:00 ETDow +78.14 at 25557.54, Nasdaq +13.54 at 7787.49, S&P +9.58 at 2850.18[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is up 0.4%, while the Russell 2000 is down 0.1%.Business inventories were unchanged in June (Briefing.com consensus 0.1%). The S&P 500 is down 0.1%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.1%, and the Nasdaq Composite is down 0.2%.Looking at the S&P 500 sector standings shows consumer staples (+0.7%) and financials (+0.6%) providing some support for the broader market. Conversely, the energy (-0.8%), industrials (-0.6%), and information technology (-0.5%) sectors have been influential laggards.U.S. Treasuries have edged higher, pushing yields lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield is down three basis points to 1.55%, and the 10-yr yield is down one basis point to 1.57%. The U.S. Dollar Index is unchanged at 97.99. WTI crude is down 1.6% to $54.34/bbl.09:13 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +18.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +43.80.The stock market is on pace to open higher following positive results and guidance from Walmart (WMT 113.24, +7.04, +6.6%) and encouraging economic data. The S&P 500 futures trade 18 points, or 0.6%, above fair value in a volatile pre-market session.Walmart's impressive results and confidence, coupled with a 0.7% increase in July retail sales (Briefing.com consensus 0.3%), has reassured the market that the U.S. consumer is still in good shape. More so, it has helped the market overlook possible Chinese retaliation against the upcoming tariffs and underwhelming guidance from Cisco Systems (CSCO 47.53, -3.08, -6.1%).To be fair, China followed up and said it hopes the U.S. can meet halfway in trade talks. USTR Lighthizer, however, reportedly told China that it "wouldn't be possible" to meet "halfway," according to CNBC.U.S. Treasuries have come down from prior highs, bringing yields near their unchanged marks. The 2-yr yield is down one basis point to 1.57%, and the 10-yr yield is unchanged at 1.58%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.94.08:50 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +16.40. Today's tally was above the prior week's revised count of 211,00 (from 209,000).
