Briefing.com: Hourly In Play (R) - 13:00 ETBriefing.comJuly 5, 2019 Friday 1:05 PM ESTCopyright 2019 Briefing.com, Inc. All rights reserved.This content is provided to LexisNexis by Comtex News Network, Inc.Length: 7789 wordsBodyHourly In Play (R)Updated: 05-Jul-19 13:00 ET12:56WRAPX Midday Market Summary: Market Under Modest Pressure at MiddayThe major averages hold modest losses at midday. The S&P 500 is lower by 0.3% while the Dow (-0.2%) sits a bit closer to its flat line.Equity indices have spent the first half of the session in negative territory after the Employment Situation report for June easily exceeded estimates. The report pointed to the addition of 224,000 nonfarm payrolls (Briefing.com consensus 160,000), which reduced expectations for a sharp rate cut.Granted, the market still expects that 25-basis point rate cut will take place at the July FOMC meeting, but the implied probability of a 50-basis point cut fell to near zero (5.9%) from 29.2% on Wednesday.The reduction in rate cut hopes pressured stocks from freshly-set record highs, but the past two hours have seen a steady rebound off session lows.Nine out of eleven sectors remain in negative territory with consumer staples (-0.8%) and industrials (-0.8%) at the bottom of the leaderboard. Transport stocks contributed to early weakness in the industrials sector, but the high-beta group has taken part in the market's recent rebound, trimming its loss to 0.6%. This leaves the Dow Jones Transportation Average unchanged for the week.Another high-beta group-PHLX Semiconductor Index-has struggled to keep pace with the rebound in the broader market. The Index is down 0.9% today and it is now down 0.1% for the week after being up 5.0% on Monday morning. The broader technology sector (-0.5%), meanwhile, trades a bit behind the broader market.Biotech names are under pressure after President Trump said that his administration is preparing a "favored-nations clause" that would reduce the prices that Medicare pays for drugs. The iShares Nasdaq Biotechnology ETF (IBB 109.41, -1.52, -1.4%) is down 1.4%.On the upside, financials (+0.4%) have shown relative strength thanks to an uptick in Treasury yields. The sector has extended this week's gain to 1.9%.Treasuries trade a bit above their lows with the 10-yr yield up nine basis points at 2.04%.Reviewing the June Employment Situation Report:June nonfarm payrolls increased by 224,000 (Briefing.com consensus 160,000). Over the past three months, job gains have averaged 171,000 per month. May nonfarm payrolls revised to 72,000 from 75,000 June private sector payrolls increased by 191,000 (Briefing.com consensus 147,000) while May private sector payrolls revised to 83,000 from 90,000 June unemployment rate was 3.7% (Briefing.com consensus 3.6%), versus 3.6% in May Persons unemployed for 27 weeks or more accounted for 23.7% of the unemployed versus 22.4% in May The U6 unemployment rate, which accounts for unemployed and underemployed workers, was 7.2%, versus 7.1% in May June average hourly earnings were up 0.2% (Briefing.com consensus +0.3%), after increasing an upwardly revised 0.3% (from 0.2%) in May Over the last 12 months, average hourly earnings have risen 3.1%, versus 3.2% for the 12 months ending in May The average workweek in June was 34.4 hours (Briefing.com consensus 34.4), unchanged from May Manufacturing workweek was up 0.1 hour to 40.7 hours Factory overtime was unchanged at 3.4 hours The labor force participation rate was 62.9% in June versus 62.8% in May12:44UNG Gas-related stocks outperform as natural gas futures jump 6%SWN +3.33%, CNX +3.11%, OMP +3.10%, RRC +3.03%, GPOR +2.68%, LPI +2.49%, CPE +2.48%, TALO +2.42%, NOG +2.32%, EQT +2.12%, DNR +2.08%, ISRL +1.94%, ESTE +1.84%, EGY +1.81%, CRC +1.68%, ERF +1.65%, GNE +1.43%, etc...12:07SCANX Small cap notable movers of interest -- DBV Technologies (DBVT) posts continued gains -Technical-The following are some of today's most notable small cap movers of interest ($300 mln - $2 bln market cap), ranked by % change (all stocks over 100K average daily volume).Small Cap GainersDBVT (10.67 +13%): Continued strength; the stock has now added circa +23% in the most recent two sessions, with investors awaiting the Q3 BLA submission for Viaskin in the treatment of peanut-allergic children aged 4 to 11 years old. Why? Because the June employment report was too strong and cut into the stock market's aggressive rate-cut hopes.Specifically, the 224,000 increase in nonfarm payrolls and 3.1% yr/yr increase in average hourly earnings wiped away the possibility of a 50 basis points cut at the July 30-31 FOMC meeting.According to the CME FedWatch Tool, there was a 25.6% probability of a 50 basis points cut before the jobs report was released. Now, there is zero probability; in fact, the CME FedWatch Tool is showing a 4.4% probability of the Fed leaving the target range for the fed funds rate unchanged at the July meeting.The shift in rate-cut expectations has been pronounced as well in the Treasury market, which is weak across the board, in the U.S. Dollar Index, which is up 0.6% to 97.35, and in gold futures, which are down 2.0% to $1392.30/troy oz.The 2-yr note yield, which is highly sensitive to changes in the fed funds rate, is up 13 basis points to 1.88%. The 10-yr note yield is up 11 basis points to 2.06%.Not surprisingly, the equity sectors regarded as bond proxies for their high yields -- real estate, (-1.5%), utilities (-1.2%), and consumer staples (-1.2%) -- are leading today's losses.Every sector, however, is trading lower as the spike in market rates, and the dashing of aggressive rate-cut hopes that had helped drive the indices to record levels, have served as profit-taking catalysts along with a separate Bloomberg report that China is saying it won't do a trade deal unless the U.S. removes all tariffs on Chinese goods.The Russell 2000 is down 0.6%; the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.6%; the S&P 500 is down 0.7%; and the Nasdaq Composite is down 0.8%.10:00DB Deutsche Bank President Garth Ritchie to leave by mutual agreement (8.24 +0.43)Garth Ritchie, President of Deutsche Bank and Head of the Corporate & Investment Bank, is leaving the bank by mutual agreement. Ritchie will be stepping down as Head of CIB and as a member of the Management Board on July 31. To ensure a smooth transition of time critical UK regulatory matters including Brexit-related issues he will continue to advise the bank until end of November 2019.09:45XLF Financial Select Sector SPDR (28.16 +0.08)The financial sector (+0.2%) has opened today in a position of relative strength; in fact, it is the only sector showing any strength at the moment.Financials have been pressured by falling rates and concerns about fading net interest margins, but with the spike in market rates today following the stronger-than-expected June jobs report, they are getting some relief.The 2-yr note yield is up 11 basis points to 1.86% while the 10-yr note has jumped nine basis points to 2.04%.Online brokers Charles Schwab (SCHW 41.26, +0.81, +2.0%), E*Trade (ETFC 46.50, +0.97, +2.2%), and TD Ameritrade (AMTD 51.28, +1.01, +2.0%) are among the early standouts along with the likes of Bank of America (BAC 29.35, +0.30, +1.0%), Goldman Sachs (GS 208.00, +1.96, +1.0%), and JPMorgan Chase (JPM 113.50, +0.68, +0.6%).09:44WRAPX Opening Market Summary: Rate-Sensitive Sectors Pace Opening DeclineThe stock market has started the day in negative territory amid losses in most sectors. The plants include the casthouses at both facilities and the paste plant at La Corua, which are currently in operation, and the two curtailed smelters. Alcoa has reached an agreement with the workers' representatives relating to a transaction between the company and PARTER Capital Group AG. However, a final acquisition is subject to a buyer-provided credit facility to support future operations. If the acquisition cannot be completed by July 31 (extended from the original June 30 deadline), the collective dismissal and social plan are expected to go into effect on August 1, 2019. Alcoa reached an agreement in January 2019 with the workers' representatives at the two aluminum plants as part of the collective dismissal process announced in October 2018. As part of that agreement, the smelters, with combined operating capacity of 124,000 metric tons per year, were curtailed in February and maintained in restart condition.Alcoa expects to record restructuring-related charges in the third quarter of 2019, rather than in the second quarter of 2019, estimated to range from $100-140 mln, or $0.54 to $0.75 per share, depending on whether an acquisition or collective dismissal occurs. Related cash outlays are expected to be approximately $100-130 mln, with approximately half to be paid in 2019.09:13WRAPX S&P futures vs fair value: -14.40. Of the 49 patients, 38 patients were evaluable for efficacy, as defined in the protocol. In this study, based on information available as of April 25, 2019, the median overall survival of evaluable patients (38 of 49) was 6.4 months. Certain efficacy indicators correlated with greater OS, including achieving SD or better and decreases in CTCs.07:55WRAPX S&P futures vs fair value: -4.40. These initial data support the ability of the company's novel inhibitory peptide TIM (T cell receptor (TCR) Inhibiting Molecule) to reduce signaling of the TCR complex Host-versus-Graft (HvG) response against the allogeneic CYAD-101 cells appears to be controlled as evidenced by similar levels of CYAD-101 cell engraftment following the second and third infusions of the allogeneic cell therapy At the dose levels evaluated, the treatment with CYAD-101 in association with FOLFOX chemotherapy was well-tolerated, with no reports of CRS, related SAEs, DLTs, nor on-target off-tumor toxicity Encouraging anti-tumor activity was observed in one patient experiencing a partial response (PR) and three patients experiencing stable disease (SD) at month 3 CYAD-101 appears to provide better relative cell engraftment as compared to CYAD-01, at the same dose levels Recruitment in DL-3 (1x109 cells) of the alloSHRINK trial is ongoing and preliminary results from the cohort are expected by year-end 2019THINK CyFlu Phase 1 Cohort UpdateTreatment with CYAD-01 following CyFlu was well tolerated with no reports of CRS grade 2 or higher, related SAEs, DLTs, nor on-target off-tumor toxicity Translational data from the cohort also suggest an improvement in cell engraftment of CYAD-01 induced by the CyFlu preconditioning as compared to the same dose of CYAD-01 without preconditioning chemotherapy Of the three patients enrolled, one patient achieved stable disease (SD), while two patients experienced disease progression06:00SUMRX Overnight Summary -- World markets provide no fireworks ahead of US Jobs dataThe global equity markets are little changed heading into the US Jobs report later this morning. The stock market, in fact, has spent the better part of the past three hours reclaiming what it lost in the early going.The rebound effort is understandable. After all, the initial burst of selling was predicated on the disappointment that the jobs report effectively negated the likelihood of a 50-basis points cut at the July 30-31 FOMC meeting. That thinking was evident in the fed funds futures market, which has seen a 25.6% probability of such a move reduced to a current 5.9% (it went to 0% earlier in the day).The residual, however, isn't all that bad -- not at least in terms of how the stock market views things. The residual is a 100% probability of a 25-basis point cut at the July meeting.So, the pairing of strong hiring activity in June with the strongest probability of a 25-basis point rate cut offered a stopgap of sorts for the gap-down beginning.This is how the market sees things. The Fed might have a different say on things come July 30-31, but if one needs a rationale for the turnaround effort, it would be the idea that the stock market still thinks it is going to get its cake (albeit without the icing) and be able to eat it, too.Most sectors are still lower for the day, but all are well off their lows; meanwhile, three sectors -- financials (+0.3%), consumer discretionary (+0.2%), and communication services (+0.1%) -- have pushed into positive territory, offering an influential measure of support.The Russell 2000 is up 0.2%; the S&P 500 is down 0.2%; the Nasdaq Composite is down 0.2%; and the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.2%.13:28EWZ iShares Brazil ETF: Brazil stocks boosted by pension reform progress and strong airline dataBrazilian stocks are notable winners today, mostly on positive reaction to a key congressional committee in Brazil approving a reform platform to tackle Brazil's bloated pension problem. The hope is full passage will come later this year. Investors are seeing this a a positive sign.Another tailwind has been strong June traffic data from two major airlines (AZUL and GOL), which we take as a sign that Brazilian consumers are becoming more confident in their economic outlook and booking more flights.Winners: GOL +20.5%, AZUL +12.4%, SBS +5%, GGB +4%, BBD +4%, ITUB +4%, EWZ +3%.12:56WRAPX Midday Market Summary: Market Under Modest Pressure at MiddayThe major averages hold modest losses at midday. The S&P 500 is lower by 0.3% while the Dow (-0.2%) sits a bit closer to its flat line.Equity indices have spent the first half of the session in negative territory after the Employment Situation report for June easily exceeded estimates. The report pointed to the addition of 224,000 nonfarm payrolls (Briefing.com consensus 160,000), which reduced expectations for a sharp rate cut.Granted, the market still expects that 25-basis point rate cut will take place at the July FOMC meeting, but the implied probability of a 50-basis point cut fell to near zero (5.9%) from 29.2% on Wednesday.The reduction in rate cut hopes pressured stocks from freshly-set record highs, but the past two hours have seen a steady rebound off session lows.Nine out of eleven sectors remain in negative territory with consumer staples (-0.8%) and industrials (-0.8%) at the bottom of the leaderboard. Transport stocks contributed to early weakness in the industrials sector, but the high-beta group has taken part in the market's recent rebound, trimming its loss to 0.6%. This leaves the Dow Jones Transportation Average unchanged for the week.Another high-beta group-PHLX Semiconductor Index-has struggled to keep pace with the rebound in the broader market. The Index is down 0.9% today and it is now down 0.1% for the week after being up 5.0% on Monday morning. The broader technology sector (-0.5%), meanwhile, trades a bit behind the broader market.Biotech names are under pressure after President Trump said that his administration is preparing a "favored-nations clause" that would reduce the prices that Medicare pays for drugs. The iShares Nasdaq Biotechnology ETF (IBB 109.41, -1.52, -1.4%) is down 1.4%.On the upside, financials (+0.4%) have shown relative strength thanks to an uptick in Treasury yields. The sector has extended this week's gain to 1.9%.Treasuries trade a bit above their lows with the 10-yr yield up nine basis points at 2.04%.Reviewing the June Employment Situation Report:June nonfarm payrolls increased by 224,000 (Briefing.com consensus 160,000). Over the past three months, job gains have averaged 171,000 per month. May nonfarm payrolls revised to 72,000 from 75,000 June private sector payrolls increased by 191,000 (Briefing.com consensus 147,000) while May private sector payrolls revised to 83,000 from 90,000 June unemployment rate was 3.7% (Briefing.com consensus 3.6%), versus 3.6% in May Persons unemployed for 27 weeks or more accounted for 23.7% of the unemployed versus 22.4% in May The U6 unemployment rate, which accounts for unemployed and underemployed workers, was 7.2%, versus 7.1% in May June average hourly earnings were up 0.2% (Briefing.com consensus +0.3%), after increasing an upwardly revised 0.3% (from 0.2%) in May Over the last 12 months, average hourly earnings have risen 3.1%, versus 3.2% for the 12 months ending in May The average workweek in June was 34.4 hours (Briefing.com consensus 34.4), unchanged from May Manufacturing workweek was up 0.1 hour to 40.7 hours Factory overtime was unchanged at 3.4 hours The labor force participation rate was 62.9% in June versus 62.8% in May12:44UNG Gas-related stocks outperform as natural gas futures jump 6%SWN +3.33%, CNX +3.11%, OMP +3.10%, RRC +3.03%, GPOR +2.68%, LPI +2.49%, CPE +2.48%, TALO +2.42%, NOG +2.32%, EQT +2.12%, DNR +2.08%, ISRL +1.94%, ESTE +1.84%, EGY +1.81%, CRC +1.68%, ERF +1.65%, GNE +1.43%, etc...12:07SCANX Small cap notable movers of interest -- DBV Technologies (DBVT) posts continued gains -Technical-The following are some of today's most notable small cap movers of interest ($300 mln - $2 bln market cap), ranked by % change (all stocks over 100K average daily volume).Small Cap GainersDBVT (10.67 +13%): Continued strength; the stock has now added circa +23% in the most recent two sessions, with investors awaiting the Q3 BLA submission for Viaskin in the treatment of peanut-allergic children aged 4 to 11 years old. Why? Because the June employment report was too strong and cut into the stock market's aggressive rate-cut hopes.Specifically, the 224,000 increase in nonfarm payrolls and 3.1% yr/yr increase in average hourly earnings wiped away the possibility of a 50 basis points cut at the July 30-31 FOMC meeting.According to the CME FedWatch Tool, there was a 25.6% probability of a 50 basis points cut before the jobs report was released. Now, there is zero probability; in fact, the CME FedWatch Tool is showing a 4.4% probability of the Fed leaving the target range for the fed funds rate unchanged at the July meeting.The shift in rate-cut expectations has been pronounced as well in the Treasury market, which is weak across the board, in the U.S. Dollar Index, which is up 0.6% to 97.35, and in gold futures, which are down 2.0% to $1392.30/troy oz.The 2-yr note yield, which is highly sensitive to changes in the fed funds rate, is up 13 basis points to 1.88%. The 10-yr note yield is up 11 basis points to 2.06%.Not surprisingly, the equity sectors regarded as bond proxies for their high yields -- real estate, (-1.5%), utilities (-1.2%), and consumer staples (-1.2%) -- are leading today's losses.Every sector, however, is trading lower as the spike in market rates, and the dashing of aggressive rate-cut hopes that had helped drive the indices to record levels, have served as profit-taking catalysts along with a separate Bloomberg report that China is saying it won't do a trade deal unless the U.S. removes all tariffs on Chinese goods.The Russell 2000 is down 0.6%; the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.6%; the S&P 500 is down 0.7%; and the Nasdaq Composite is down 0.8%.10:00DB Deutsche Bank President Garth Ritchie to leave by mutual agreement (8.24 +0.43)Garth Ritchie, President of Deutsche Bank and Head of the Corporate & Investment Bank, is leaving the bank by mutual agreement. Ritchie will be stepping down as Head of CIB and as a member of the Management Board on July 31. To ensure a smooth transition of time critical UK regulatory matters including Brexit-related issues he will continue to advise the bank until end of November 2019.09:45XLF Financial Select Sector SPDR (28.16 +0.08)The financial sector (+0.2%) has opened today in a position of relative strength; in fact, it is the only sector showing any strength at the moment.Financials have been pressured by falling rates and concerns about fading net interest margins, but with the spike in market rates today following the stronger-than-expected June jobs report, they are getting some relief.The 2-yr note yield is up 11 basis points to 1.86% while the 10-yr note has jumped nine basis points to 2.04%.Online brokers Charles Schwab (SCHW 41.26, +0.81, +2.0%), E*Trade (ETFC 46.50, +0.97, +2.2%), and TD Ameritrade (AMTD 51.28, +1.01, +2.0%) are among the early standouts along with the likes of Bank of America (BAC 29.35, +0.30, +1.0%), Goldman Sachs (GS 208.00, +1.96, +1.0%), and JPMorgan Chase (JPM 113.50, +0.68, +0.6%).09:44WRAPX Opening Market Summary: Rate-Sensitive Sectors Pace Opening DeclineThe stock market has started the day in negative territory amid losses in most sectors. The S&P 500 trades lower by 0.6% with ten out of eleven sectors in the red.Rate-sensitive groups are among the early laggards. Real estate (-1.6%), utilities (-1.3%), and consumer staples (-1.0%) sit at the bottom of the leaderboard. Conversely, financials (+0.3%) trade in the green as weakness in Treasuries boosts yields.Treasuries sit on their lows with the 10-yr yield up nine basis points at 2.04%.09:32WP Worldpay/Fidelity Nat'l Info (FIS) secure European Commission approval for pending merger; deal has now received all required regulatory approvals needed for consummation (126.97 -1.07)Subject to the satisfaction or waiver of the remaining customary contractual conditions set forth in the Merger Agreement, including receipt of the requisite shareholder approvals at each of FIS' and Worldpay's special meetings to be held on July 24, 2019, the parties expect to consummate the Merger on or about July 31, 2019.09:22AA Alcoa announces updates on Avils and La Corua aluminum plants in Spain and expected restructuring charges (22.70 )Alcoa has signed a conditional share purchase agreement with private equity investment firm PARTER Capital Group AG to acquire the Alcoa Avils and La Corua aluminum plants in Spain. The plants include the casthouses at both facilities and the paste plant at La Corua, which are currently in operation, and the two curtailed smelters. Alcoa has reached an agreement with the workers' representatives relating to a transaction between the company and PARTER Capital Group AG. However, a final acquisition is subject to a buyer-provided credit facility to support future operations. If the acquisition cannot be completed by July 31 (extended from the original June 30 deadline), the collective dismissal and social plan are expected to go into effect on August 1, 2019. Alcoa reached an agreement in January 2019 with the workers' representatives at the two aluminum plants as part of the collective dismissal process announced in October 2018. As part of that agreement, the smelters, with combined operating capacity of 124,000 metric tons per year, were curtailed in February and maintained in restart condition.Alcoa expects to record restructuring-related charges in the third quarter of 2019, rather than in the second quarter of 2019, estimated to range from $100-140 mln, or $0.54 to $0.75 per share, depending on whether an acquisition or collective dismissal occurs. Related cash outlays are expected to be approximately $100-130 mln, with approximately half to be paid in 2019.09:13WRAPX S&P futures vs fair value: -14.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -57.20.The stock market is on track for a lower start as futures on the S&P 500 trade 14 points below fair value.Index futures held modest losses in early-morning trade, but they slid to lows after the release of a June Employment Situation report that was comfortably ahead of estimates. The fed funds futures market now sees just an 8.0% implied likelihood of a 50-basis point rate cut in July, down from 29.2% on Wednesday. The fed funds futures market remains certain that a 25-basis point rate cut will take place on July 31.Treasuries retreated in response to today's data, sliding toward this week's lows. The 10-yr yield is up seven basis points at 2.02% while the 2-yr yield is up eight basis points at 1.84%. Of the 49 patients, 38 patients were evaluable for efficacy, as defined in the protocol. In this study, based on information available as of April 25, 2019, the median overall survival of evaluable patients (38 of 49) was 6.4 months. Certain efficacy indicators correlated with greater OS, including achieving SD or better and decreases in CTCs.07:55WRAPX S&P futures vs fair value: -4.40. Fugitive billionaire Guo Wengui: Communist Party 'destroying itself'UPIAugust 12, 2019 Monday 10:56 AM ESTCopyright 2019 U.P.I. All Rights ReservedLength: 376 wordsByline: ELIZABETH SHIMDateline: Dec. 31 BodyA fugitive Chinese billionaire who has previously met with U.S. President 's former senior counselor  said internal weakness in the Chinese Communist Party raises concerns about its long-term stability.Guo Wengui, who lives in New York and has pledged to expose political corruption in China, said he has privately met with Chinese Communist Party officials who voice doubts about the future, Taiwan's Liberty Times reported Monday.Guo, who made his fortune in Chinese real estate before fleeing the country, said one "senior member" is skeptical the annual Beidaihe summit will take place next year, citing political upheaval and internal party divisions, according to the report.The meeting at Beidaihe holds symbolic importance for the Communist Party. It involves former and incumbent Chinese officials of the highest rank, and takes place in late July or early August each year. The meeting takes place in a resort area about 170 miles east of Beijing.According to Guo, the Chinese government source said multiple crises are facing the world's second-largest economy, including the protests in Hong Kong, China's economic downturn and fiscal deficit, potential revolt in Xinjiang and Tibet, as well as growing popular opposition toward Internet censorship.Guo did not reveal the identity of his source, who had recently attended this year's Beidaihe meeting. He said his source "made history" at the 18th National Congress of the Communist Party, held in November 2012. The Chinese billionaire added his description should make it easy to identify his source, and said the "important point, where the Chinese Communist Party is destroying itself, has already begun," according to Liberty Times.Guo left China after August 2014, when Chinese authorities began to investigate him for corruption. He has claimed he is the victim of false accusations and government graft.Guo's statements to the Taiwanese press comes at a time when violent footage of the police crackdown against protesters in Hong Kong continues to be uploaded to social media.The BBC's Stephen McDonell tweeted Sunday Hong Kong police mercilessly beat local protesters, and included footage from Hong Kong's Apple Daily, showing the violence taking place at a subway station in the city.Load-Date: August 13, 2019End of Document

Mnuchin Expects Shanghai Meeting To Be Followed By More Rounds Of TalksThe FrontrunnerJuly 25, 2019 ThursdayCopyright 2019 Bulletin News Network, Inc.Section: INTERNATIONAL NEWSLength: 431 wordsBodyReuters (7/24) reports the White House confirmed Wednesday that US and Chinese officials "will meet face-to-face next week for the first time since" President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping "agreed in June to revive talks aimed at ending a yearlong trade war between the world's two largest economies." Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and USTR Lighthizer "will lead a team of American officials in discussions in Shanghai" starting on Tuesday with Chinese Vice Premier Liu He. Mnuchin told reporters at the White House yesterday, "There'll be a few more meetings before we get a deal done. I wouldn't expect that we'll resolve all the issues. But the fact that we're back at the table at the direction of the two presidents is important."Asked on CNBC's Squawk Box (7/24, 114K) about the progress of US-China trade negotiations, Mnuchin said, "There's a significance to them of the Shanghai Communique and the symbolism, obviously, of that important agreement. So hopefully I'll take that as good news, that we'll be making progress next week. But I would say there's a lot of issues, so my expectation this will be followed up with a meeting back in [Washington]...and hopefully we'll continue to progress."Mnuchin: Trump Unconcerned By Google's Work For Chinese Government.Asked on CNBC's Squawk Box (7/24, 114K) about Peter Thiel's charge that Alphabet and Google's cooperation with China, alongside its reluctance to work with the Pentagon, verges on "treasonous," Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he and President Trump have both "look[ed] into that." According to Mnuchin, Google has "assured us that there is very, very limited work. The only work they're doing is some minimal open source work. They continue to do work with us in certain areas of DOD. I think Google is an American company that wants to help out the US." Mnuchin added, "Again, the President and I looked at this, and we're not aware of Google working with the Chinese government in a way that raises concerns."In its report on Mnuchin's remarks, the Wall Street Journal (7/24, Tweh, Subscription Publication, 7.57M) notes that earlier this month, Thiel called for the FBI and CIA to investigate Google for working with China, and Trump tweeted last week that his Administration would study claims by Thiel, who served on his White House transition team.WSJournal A1 Analysis: Europe Caught In Middle Of US-China Trade Tensions.A front-page Wall Street Journal (7/24, A1, Hannon, Kostov, Subscription Publication, 7.57M) analysis says Europe is suffering from the ongoing trade tensions between the US and China.Load-Date: July 25, 2019End of Document

Google Executive Tells Senate Hearing It Has Ended Censored Search Engine Project for ChinaMT Newswires Live BriefsJuly 17, 2019 Wednesday 5:52 AM ESTCopyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights ReservedLength: 127 wordsBody A top official from Google (GOOG, GOOGL) told US senators at a hearing on Tuesday that the company has discontinued its censored search engine project for China, according to published reports.Karan Bhatia, the company's government affairs and public policy chief, confirmed to Senator Josh Hawley of Missouri that the search engine project, dubbed Project Dragonfly, has been abandoned. Bhatia, however, would not commit to Google never considering another project that would comply with the state security requirements of the Chinese government, according to reports.Bhatia appeared at the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee hearing to respond to allegations that Google is actively suppressing conservative voices.Price: 1,153.58, Change: +3.24, Percent Change: +0.28Load-Date: July 18, 2019End of Document

The 2019 China Digital Entertainment Congress (CDEC) kicks off in Shanghai; At the event Perfect World CEO Dr. Robert Hong Xiao speaks about new development of the digital cultural and creative industryPR NewswireAugust 6, 2019 Tuesday 7:21 AM ESTCopyright 2019 PR Newswire Association LLC All Rights ReservedLength: 584 wordsDateline: SHANGHAI, Aug. 6, 2019 BodyPR NewswireThe 2019 China Digital Entertainment Congress (CDEC), with the theme of "Challenges, Opportunities and Dreams", kicked off in Shanghai on August 1.As one of the most professional, authoritative and internationally influential events in the Chinese digital entertainment sector, CDEC has attracted a number of well-known Chinese digital entertainment companies including Tencent, NetEase, Perfect World, Giant Interactive Group and Shengqu Games. It is an occasion for the enterprises to join hands to initiate the transformation of the cultural and creative industry in the new digital era, as well as to provide the world's digital entertainment community with preemptive opportunities brought about by the development of a Chinese digital entertainment ecosystem."The digital cultural and creative industry has excelled in delivering an outstanding experience and more value to users and in connecting with them emotionally. Digital cultural and creative companies can leverage this unique advantage to enable the transformation of the traditional cultural and entertainment sectors and to explore and create new momentum together with traditional players," said Perfect World CEO Dr. Robert Hong Xiao at the conference during his keynote speech."In addition, the implementation of 5G technologies is expected to fundamentally change the e-sports sector, delivering a new exciting gaming experience to users by transforming the previous forms of entertainment on both the production and consumption sides. 5G technologies are on track to boost the development of e-sports while bringing new approaches to traditional sports."The digital cultural and creative industry, one of the most dynamic within China's national economy, has not only transformed the way cultural content is produced, communicated and consumed, but has also empowered and rejuvenated the traditional side of the sector.Taking e-sports, an emerging sector within the industry, as an example, the sector, by collaborating with counterparts in the larger entertainment content sector, has generated a number of new forms of entertainment, including e-sports variety shows, live events, movies and music, delivering an unprecedented variety of new experiences to consumers. By empowering other traditional cultural and entertainment sectors, e-sports is also likely to create new business models, including e-sports-themed tourism, finance, e-commerce and training.E-sports has gradually become a platform for mass entrepreneurship and innovation while providing new opportunities to the governments of many Chinese cities. The future of the larger industry, including e-sports, is promising due to its unique features and advantages. It has become the common mission of all industry players to explore how to unlock the industry's potential value via innovation.As a high-end authoritative conference that is held concurrently with China Digital Entertainment Expo and Conference (ChinaJoy), CDEC has been held for 16 consecutive years since its launch in 2003. CDEC has been and continues to be highly valued by government officials, with many attending in person. CDEC is also a not-to-missed event for many executives from internationally renowned digital entertainment companies who make sure to be present every year. View original content to download multimedia:http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-2019-china-digital-entertainment-congress-cdec-kicks-off-in-shanghai-300897090.htmlSOURCE Perfect World Co., Ltd.CONTACT: Ximeng Chen, +86-10-5780-6664, chenximeng@pwrd.comLoad-Date: August 7, 2019End of Document

Specifically, the president tweeted that there are "no signs" that China has begun to buy U.S. agricultural products. The topic is likely to come up during the ongoing trade talks in Shanghai.In addition, the 16% drop in shares of Beyond Meat (BYND 186.10, -36.03, -16.2%) following its earnings report has perhaps reflected some complacency in the economic growth outlook.Dow components Procter & Gamble (PG 121.39, +5.39, +4.7%) and Merck (MRK 84.87, +2.38, +2.9%) have provided some support for the market after both beat top and bottom-line estimates. Fellow Dow member Pfizer (PFE 40.40, -1.05, -2.5%) is down after Bank of America/Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley downgraded the stock to the equivalent of a Neutral rating.Earlier, the S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May increased 2.4% (Briefing.com consensus 3.5%) after increasing 2.5% in April.08:50 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -15.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -62.60.The S&P 500 futures trade 15 points, or 0.5%, below fair value.Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended Tuesday on a mostly higher note. Nikkei reported that more than two thirds of manufacturers in Japan have seen lower quarterly profits in Q2, representing the largest share since the financial crisis. Japan's Cabinet office lowered expectations for growth in fiscal 2019/2020 to 1.3% from 0.9%. The Bank of Japan made no changes to its policy stance, reiterating its readiness to step up easing efforts. The Chinese government reiterated its support Hong Kong's Chief Executive Officer Carrie Lam amid continuing protests.In economic data: Japan's June Industrial Production -3.6% m/m (expected -2.0%; last 2.0%) and June Unemployment Rate 2.3% (expected 2.4%; last 2.4%) South Korea's August Manufacturing BSI Index 74 (last 76) Australia's June Building Approvals -1.2% m/m (expected 0.2%; last 0.3%) and Private House Approvals +0.4% (last -0.3%) New Zealand's June Building Consents -3.9% m/m (last 13.5%)---Equity Markets---Japan's Nikkei: +0.4% Hong Kong's Hang Seng: +0.1% China's Shanghai Composite: +0.4% India's Sensex: -0.8% South Korea's Kospi: +0.5% Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.2%Major European indices trade in negative territory with bank stocks among the laggards. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -52.40.The S&P 500 futures trade 13 points, or 0.4%, below fair value.Just in, personal income increased 0.4% in June, as expected, following a revised increase of 0.4% in May (from 0.5%). Personal spending increased 0.3% (Briefing.com consensus +0.4%) following a revised increase of 0.5% in May (from 0.4%).The PCE Price Index increased 0.1% in June, and the core reading, which excludes food and energy, increased 0.2%. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -55.60.The S&P 500 futures trade 14 points, or 0.5%, below fair value and have recently slipped to session lows after President Trump tweeted that China has yet to begin buying U.S. agricultural products.Prior to the president's tweet, there was already a negative tilt in the futures trade as a lack of buying interest seemed to be carrying over from yesterday's session. In the meantime, U.S.-China trade talks are ongoing in China where negotiations can turn to address President Trump's concerns.Separately, the Federal Open Market Committee will kick off its two-day policy meeting today. The Bank of Japan for its part made no changes to its policy stance and reiterated its readiness to step up easing efforts.Before its rate decision tomorrow, the Fed will have a look at its preferred inflation gauge -- the PCE Price Index (Briefing.com consensus 0.1%) -- in the June report for Personal Income (Briefing.com consensus 0.4%) and Spending (Briefing.com consensus 0.3%) at 8:30 a.m. ET.Investors will also receive the S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May (Briefing.com consensus 3.5%) at 9:00 a.m. ET, and the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for July (Briefing.com consensus 125.5) and Pending Home Sales for June (Briefing.com consensus 1.0%) at 10:00 a.m. ET.U.S. Treasuries are little changed. The 2-yr yield is unchanged at 2.84%, and the 10-yr yield is down one basis point to 2.05%. The U.S. Dollar Index is flat at 98.07. WTI crude is up 0.8% to $57.30/bbl.In U.S. Corporate news:Procter & Gamble (PG 120.20, +4.20): +3.6% after beating top and bottom-line estimates. Merck (MRK 84.99, +2.50): +3.0% after beating top and bottom-line estimates and raising its full-year guidance above consensus. Capital One (COF 92.01, -4.91): -5.1% after announcing a security breach that affected around 100 million individuals in the United States. The company beat revenue estimates and raised its full-year revenue guidance above consensus.Reviewing overnight developments:Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended Tuesday on a mostly higher note. DAX...12253.4...-164.10...-1.30%.16:15 ETDow +28.90 at 27221.35, Nasdaq -36.88 at 8293.33, S&P -4.89 at 3020.97[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 lost 0.2% on Monday, slipping from record highs in a lackluster session. The Nasdaq Composite (-0.4%) and Russell 2000 (-0.6%) both underperformed, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.1%) managed to finish higher.Monday's session didn't include much price action, as investors appeared to be waiting for several key events later this week. Some of these events will include the FOMC's rate decision, U.S.-China trade talks, the July employment report, and Apple's (AAPL 209.68, +1.94, +0.9%) earnings report. On a related note, Apple's price target was raised to $235 from $225 at UBS before its results after Tuesday's close.Apple shares rose on the increased price target, but the broader market was still weighed down by widely-held shares of Amazon (AMZN 1912.45, -30.60, -1.6%), Facebook (FB 195.94, -3.81, -1.9%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1239.41, -11.00, -0.9%). In turn, the S&P 500 consumer discretionary (-0.6%) and communication services (-0.5%) sectors were among today's laggards but, like the broader market, finished the session off intraday lows.The S&P 500 financials sector (-0.8%) succumbed to broad-based selling interest throughout the day. Wells Fargo (WFC 48.28, -1.02, -2.1%) was a notable laggard amid a Wall Street Journal report indicating that the Trump administration plans to make it harder for deeply indebted borrowers to acquire mortgage loans.On the other hand, the S&P 500 defensive-oriented sectors -- utilities (+0.5%), real estate (+0.5%), health care (+0.4%), and consumer staples (+0.3%) -- were the lone sectors that finished higher.Separately, Mylan N.V. (MYL 20.78, +2.32, +12.6%) agreed to combine with Pfizer's (PFE 41.45, -1.64, -3.8%) off-patent drug business, giving Mylan shareholders 43% of the combined company. On a related note, Mylan N.V. beat top and bottom-line estimates; Pfizer beat earnings estimates but missed revenue estimates.U.S. Treasuries finished the session higher, pushing yields lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield declined three basis points each to 1.84% and 2.06%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index finished flat at 98.04. WTI crude increased 1.2% to $56.87/bbl.Investors did not receive any notable economic data on Monday.Looking ahead, Tuesday will feature the Personal Income and Spending report for June, which will include the Fed's preferred inflation gauge -- the PCE Price Index. Investors will also receive the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for July, Pending Home Sales for June, and the S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May.Nasdaq Composite +25.0% YTDS&P 500 +20.5% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +16.7% YTDRussell 2000 +16.4% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1472/1420. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1183/1867.Briefing.com is the leading Internet provider of live market analysis for U.S. Stock, U.S. Bond and world FX market participants. 1-800-752-3013 or http://www.briefing.comLoad-Date: July 30, 2019End of Document

The blue-chip average, however, is being pressured by losses in most components, including Pfizer (PFE 39.32, -2.12, -5.1%), which was downgraded at Bank of America/Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley.Separately, shares of Capital One (COF 90.05, -6.87, -7.1%) are getting hit after the company announced a data breach that affected around 100 million customers in the United States and six million in Canada. The suspected hacker has been arrested.10:55 ETDow -46.35 at 27175, Nasdaq -27.63 at 8265.7, S&P -9.07 at 3011.9[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades lower by 0.4%, recouping some of its opening losses. Today's lower start has reflected some consolidation from record highs, but there have also been some convenient selling narratives.One of those includes President Trump calling out China for not buying U.S. agricultural products despite it agreeing to do so. Another one could be a lack of buying interest, much like yesterday, in front of the Fed's rate decision tomorrow.Separately, shares of Beyond Meat (BYND 199.40, -22.73) have dropped 10.3% following its earnings report. It wasn't a bad report, per se, but the company announcing a secondary stock offering has undercut sentiment for this year's hottest stock. In addition, its poor showing today has caused some investors to reconsider stocks that have also caught fire this year.10:30 ETDow -70.77 at 27150.58, Nasdaq -37.70 at 8255.63, S&P -11.72 at 3009.25[BRIEFING.COM] Commodities are lower (-0.2% at 78.88 as measured by the Bloomberg Commodity Index)Dollar index is higher (+0.1% at 98.11)Looking at energy:Aug WTI crude oil futures are now +$0.28 (+0.5%) at $57.16/barrel Aug natural gas is +$0.01 (-0.8%) at $2.13/MMBtuMoving on to metals:Aug gold is currently +$6.20 at $1426.70/oz, while Jul silver is +$0.06 (+0.4%) at $16.51/ozSept copper is now -$0.03 (-1.2%) at $2.68/lb ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1084/1697. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1070/1739.10:05 ETDow -70.83 at 27150.52, Nasdaq -41.09 at 8252.24, S&P -11.00 at 3009.97[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades lower by 0.4%, and the Russell 2000 trades lower by 0.5%.Just in, the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index increased to 135.7 in July (Briefing.com consensus 125.5) from a revised 124.3 in June (from 121.5).Separately, Pending Home Sales increased 1.6% in June (Briefing.com consensus +1.0%). DAX...12253.4...-164.10...-1.30%.16:15 ETDow +28.90 at 27221.35, Nasdaq -36.88 at 8293.33, S&P -4.89 at 3020.97[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 lost 0.2% on Monday, slipping from record highs in a lackluster session. The Nasdaq Composite (-0.4%) and Russell 2000 (-0.6%) both underperformed, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.1%) managed to finish higher.Monday's session didn't include much price action, as investors appeared to be waiting for several key events later this week. Some of these events will include the FOMC's rate decision, U.S.-China trade talks, the July employment report, and Apple's (AAPL 209.68, +1.94, +0.9%) earnings report. On a related note, Apple's price target was raised to $235 from $225 at UBS before its results after Tuesday's close.Apple shares rose on the increased price target, but the broader market was still weighed down by widely-held shares of Amazon (AMZN 1912.45, -30.60, -1.6%), Facebook (FB 195.94, -3.81, -1.9%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1239.41, -11.00, -0.9%). In turn, the S&P 500 consumer discretionary (-0.6%) and communication services (-0.5%) sectors were among today's laggards but, like the broader market, finished the session off intraday lows.The S&P 500 financials sector (-0.8%) succumbed to broad-based selling interest throughout the day. Wells Fargo (WFC 48.28, -1.02, -2.1%) was a notable laggard amid a Wall Street Journal report indicating that the Trump administration plans to make it harder for deeply indebted borrowers to acquire mortgage loans.On the other hand, the S&P 500 defensive-oriented sectors -- utilities (+0.5%), real estate (+0.5%), health care (+0.4%), and consumer staples (+0.3%) -- were the lone sectors that finished higher.Separately, Mylan N.V. (MYL 20.78, +2.32, +12.6%) agreed to combine with Pfizer's (PFE 41.45, -1.64, -3.8%) off-patent drug business, giving Mylan shareholders 43% of the combined company. On a related note, Mylan N.V. beat top and bottom-line estimates; Pfizer beat earnings estimates but missed revenue estimates.U.S. Treasuries finished the session higher, pushing yields lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield declined three basis points each to 1.84% and 2.06%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index finished flat at 98.04. WTI crude increased 1.2% to $56.87/bbl.Investors did not receive any notable economic data on Monday.Looking ahead, Tuesday will feature the Personal Income and Spending report for June, which will include the Fed's preferred inflation gauge -- the PCE Price Index. Investors will also receive the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for July, Pending Home Sales for June, and the S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May.Nasdaq Composite +25.0% YTDS&P 500 +20.5% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +16.7% YTDRussell 2000 +16.4% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1472/1420. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1183/1867.Briefing.com is the leading Internet provider of live market analysis for U.S. Stock, U.S. Bond and world FX market participants. 1-800-752-3013 or http://www.briefing.comLoad-Date: July 30, 2019End of Document

S&P: -9.68...NYSE Vol: 275.8 mln.. Adv: 1515.. Dec: 1349Nasdaq Vol: 814.7 mln.. Adv: 1662.. Dec: 1271Moving the MarketSector WatchSome consolidation from record highs in front of the Fed's rate decision tomorrowPresident Trump calls out China for not buying U.S. agricultural products; trade talks are ongoing in Shanghai Relative strength in the S&P 500 real estate and consumer staples sectorsStrongest consumer confidence reading since Nov. 2018Strong: Real Estate, Consumer Staples, Utilities, MaterialsWeak: Health Care, Consumer Discretionary, Financials12:25 ETDow -48.62 at 27172.73, Nasdaq -27.14 at 8266.19, S&P -9.68 at 3011.29[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market has wavered in negative territory without much conviction, much like yesterday's session. The S&P 500 is down 0.3%.Looking at the FAANG stocks shows Facebook (FB 197.14, +1.20, +0.6%) as the lone stock trading higher, while Netflix (NFLX 324.65, -8.05, -2.4%) underperforms. Apple (AAPL 2018.19, -1.50, -0.7%), Amazon (AMZN 1897.51, -14.84, -0.8%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1229.59, -9.82, -0.8%) trade with losses just below 1%.In earnings news, shares of Eli Lilly (LLY 109.46, +0.75, +0.7%) are up after the company beat profit estimates and raised its FY19 EPS outlook.11:55 ETDow -55.98 at 27165.37, Nasdaq -29.89 at 8263.44, S&P -10.57 at 3010.4[BRIEFING.COM] The rebound attempt has lost some steam, as the S&P 500 currently trades lower by 0.4%. It was still a encouraging to see the benchmark index holding above the 3000 level at its lowest point today.Apple (AAPL 208.21, -1.47, -0.7%) will take the spotlight after today's closing bell when it releases its earnings report. Analyst expectations are low, but interest is high for one of the market's most widely-owned stocks that has already surged nearly 32% this year.Overseas, the major European indices closed on lower note. Germany's DAX lost 2.1%, UK's FTSE lost 0.5%, and France's CAC lost 1.6%. The Europe Stoxx 600 declined 1.5%.11:25 ETDow -24.31 at 27197.04, Nasdaq -24.51 at 8268.82, S&P -8.12 at 3012.85[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages have pared early losses and now trade near session highs. The S&P 500 is down 0.3%, the Dow is down 0.1%, and the Nasdaq is down 0.3%.The Dow has received some support from shares of Procter & Gamble (PG 121.00, +5.00, +4.3%) and Merck (MRK 83.15, +0.65, +0.8%) following their earnings reports. The blue-chip average, however, is being pressured by losses in most components, including Pfizer (PFE 39.32, -2.12, -5.1%), which was downgraded at Bank of America/Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley.Separately, shares of Capital One (COF 90.05, -6.87, -7.1%) are getting hit after the company announced a data breach that affected around 100 million customers in the United States and six million in Canada. The suspected hacker has been arrested.10:55 ETDow -46.35 at 27175, Nasdaq -27.63 at 8265.7, S&P -9.07 at 3011.9[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades lower by 0.4%, recouping some of its opening losses. Today's lower start has reflected some consolidation from record highs, but there have also been some convenient selling narratives.One of those includes President Trump calling out China for not buying U.S. agricultural products despite it agreeing to do so. Another one could be a lack of buying interest, much like yesterday, in front of the Fed's rate decision tomorrow.Separately, shares of Beyond Meat (BYND 199.40, -22.73) have dropped 10.3% following its earnings report. It wasn't a bad report, per se, but the company announcing a secondary stock offering has undercut sentiment for this year's hottest stock. In addition, its poor showing today has caused some investors to reconsider stocks that have also caught fire this year.10:30 ETDow -70.77 at 27150.58, Nasdaq -37.70 at 8255.63, S&P -11.72 at 3009.25[BRIEFING.COM] Commodities are lower (-0.2% at 78.88 as measured by the Bloomberg Commodity Index)Dollar index is higher (+0.1% at 98.11)Looking at energy:Aug WTI crude oil futures are now +$0.28 (+0.5%) at $57.16/barrel Aug natural gas is +$0.01 (-0.8%) at $2.13/MMBtuMoving on to metals:Aug gold is currently +$6.20 at $1426.70/oz, while Jul silver is +$0.06 (+0.4%) at $16.51/ozSept copper is now -$0.03 (-1.2%) at $2.68/lb ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1084/1697. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1070/1739.10:05 ETDow -70.83 at 27150.52, Nasdaq -41.09 at 8252.24, S&P -11.00 at 3009.97[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades lower by 0.4%, and the Russell 2000 trades lower by 0.5%.Just in, the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index increased to 135.7 in July (Briefing.com consensus 125.5) from a revised 124.3 in June (from 121.5).Separately, Pending Home Sales increased 1.6% in June (Briefing.com consensus +1.0%). Today's reading follows an unrevised increase of 1.1% in May.09:45 ETDow -113.35 at 27108, Nasdaq -44.21 at 8249.12, S&P -14.31 at 3006.66[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages begin the day lower, partly due to some caution ahead of the Fed's rate decision tomorrow and negative trade rhetoric from President Trump. The S&P 500 is down 0.5%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite is down 0.5%.Looking at the S&P 500 sectors shows consumer discretionary (-0.7%), health care (-0.7%), and industrials (-0.7%) leading the market lower. Conversely, the utilities (+0.1%), consumer staples (+0.2%) and real estate (+0.6%) sectors are the lone sectors trading higher.U.S. Treasuries are trading near their unchanged marks. The 2-yr yield is up one basis point to 1.85%, and the 10-yield is down one basis point to 2.05%. The U.S. Dollar Index is up 0.1% to 98.11. WTI crude is up 0.6% to $57.20/bbl.09:15 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -15.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -59.60.The stock market is on pace to pull back further from all-time highs at the open. Currently, the S&P 500 futures trade 15 points, or 0.5%, below fair value.De-risking efforts appear to be contributing to the negative disposition, partly due to negative trade rhetoric from President Trump stirring trade concerns. Specifically, the president tweeted that there are "no signs" that China has begun to buy U.S. agricultural products. The topic is likely to come up during the ongoing trade talks in Shanghai.In addition, the 16% drop in shares of Beyond Meat (BYND 186.10, -36.03, -16.2%) following its earnings report has perhaps reflected some complacency in the economic growth outlook.Dow components Procter & Gamble (PG 121.39, +5.39, +4.7%) and Merck (MRK 84.87, +2.38, +2.9%) have provided some support for the market after both beat top and bottom-line estimates. Fellow Dow member Pfizer (PFE 40.40, -1.05, -2.5%) is down after Bank of America/Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley downgraded the stock to the equivalent of a Neutral rating.Earlier, the S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May increased 2.4% (Briefing.com consensus 3.5%) after increasing 2.5% in April.08:50 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -15.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -62.60.The S&P 500 futures trade 15 points, or 0.5%, below fair value.Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended Tuesday on a mostly higher note. Nikkei reported that more than two thirds of manufacturers in Japan have seen lower quarterly profits in Q2, representing the largest share since the financial crisis. Japan's Cabinet office lowered expectations for growth in fiscal 2019/2020 to 1.3% from 0.9%. The Bank of Japan made no changes to its policy stance, reiterating its readiness to step up easing efforts. The Chinese government reiterated its support Hong Kong's Chief Executive Officer Carrie Lam amid continuing protests.In economic data: Japan's June Industrial Production -3.6% m/m (expected -2.0%; last 2.0%) and June Unemployment Rate 2.3% (expected 2.4%; last 2.4%) South Korea's August Manufacturing BSI Index 74 (last 76) Australia's June Building Approvals -1.2% m/m (expected 0.2%; last 0.3%) and Private House Approvals +0.4% (last -0.3%) New Zealand's June Building Consents -3.9% m/m (last 13.5%)---Equity Markets---Japan's Nikkei: +0.4% Hong Kong's Hang Seng: +0.1% China's Shanghai Composite: +0.4% India's Sensex: -0.8% South Korea's Kospi: +0.5% Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.2%Major European indices trade in negative territory with bank stocks among the laggards. Lufthansa is down more than 6.0% in Frankfurt in response to disappointing results that were driven by higher costs and lower fare prices. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has reportedly refused to meet with EU leaders until they agree to remove the Irish backstop from the Brexit agreement.In economic data: Eurozone's July Business and Consumer Survey 102.7 (expected 102.6; last 103.3) Germany's August GfK Consumer Climate 9.7, as expected (last 9.8) France's flash Q2 GDP +0.2% qtr/qtr (expected 0.3%; last 0.3%). Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -52.40.The S&P 500 futures trade 13 points, or 0.4%, below fair value.Just in, personal income increased 0.4% in June, as expected, following a revised increase of 0.4% in May (from 0.5%). Personal spending increased 0.3% (Briefing.com consensus +0.4%) following a revised increase of 0.5% in May (from 0.4%).The PCE Price Index increased 0.1% in June, and the core reading, which excludes food and energy, increased 0.2%. Both increased as expected. Year-over-year, the core PCE Price Index was up 1.6%, versus from 1.5% in May.07:58 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -14.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -55.60.The S&P 500 futures trade 14 points, or 0.5%, below fair value and have recently slipped to session lows after President Trump tweeted that China has yet to begin buying U.S. agricultural products.Prior to the president's tweet, there was already a negative tilt in the futures trade as a lack of buying interest seemed to be carrying over from yesterday's session. In the meantime, U.S.-China trade talks are ongoing in China where negotiations can turn to address President Trump's concerns.Separately, the Federal Open Market Committee will kick off its two-day policy meeting today. The Bank of Japan for its part made no changes to its policy stance and reiterated its readiness to step up easing efforts.Before its rate decision tomorrow, the Fed will have a look at its preferred inflation gauge -- the PCE Price Index (Briefing.com consensus 0.1%) -- in the June report for Personal Income (Briefing.com consensus 0.4%) and Spending (Briefing.com consensus 0.3%) at 8:30 a.m. ET.Investors will also receive the S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May (Briefing.com consensus 3.5%) at 9:00 a.m. ET, and the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for July (Briefing.com consensus 125.5) and Pending Home Sales for June (Briefing.com consensus 1.0%) at 10:00 a.m. ET.U.S. Treasuries are little changed. The 2-yr yield is unchanged at 2.84%, and the 10-yr yield is down one basis point to 2.05%. The U.S. Dollar Index is flat at 98.07. WTI crude is up 0.8% to $57.30/bbl.In U.S. Corporate news:Procter & Gamble (PG 120.20, +4.20): +3.6% after beating top and bottom-line estimates. Merck (MRK 84.99, +2.50): +3.0% after beating top and bottom-line estimates and raising its full-year guidance above consensus. Pfizer (PFE 40.45, -1.00): -2.4% after the stock was downgraded to the equivalent of a Neutral rating at Bank of America/Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley. Capital One (COF 92.01, -4.91): -5.1% after announcing a security breach that affected around 100 million individuals in the United States. Eli Lilly (LLY 109.89, +1.17): +1.1% after beating earnings estimates and raising its FY19 EPS outlook.Beyond Meat (BYND 193.00, -29.13): -13.1% after missing earnings estimates and announcing a 3.25 million share proposed public offering of common stock. The company beat revenue estimates and raised its full-year revenue guidance above consensus.Reviewing overnight developments:Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended Tuesday on a mostly higher note. DAX...12253.4...-164.10...-1.30%.16:15 ETDow +28.90 at 27221.35, Nasdaq -36.88 at 8293.33, S&P -4.89 at 3020.97[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 lost 0.2% on Monday, slipping from record highs in a lackluster session. The Nasdaq Composite (-0.4%) and Russell 2000 (-0.6%) both underperformed, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.1%) managed to finish higher.Monday's session didn't include much price action, as investors appeared to be waiting for several key events later this week. Some of these events will include the FOMC's rate decision, U.S.-China trade talks, the July employment report, and Apple's (AAPL 209.68, +1.94, +0.9%) earnings report. On a related note, Apple's price target was raised to $235 from $225 at UBS before its results after Tuesday's close.Apple shares rose on the increased price target, but the broader market was still weighed down by widely-held shares of Amazon (AMZN 1912.45, -30.60, -1.6%), Facebook (FB 195.94, -3.81, -1.9%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1239.41, -11.00, -0.9%). In turn, the S&P 500 consumer discretionary (-0.6%) and communication services (-0.5%) sectors were among today's laggards but, like the broader market, finished the session off intraday lows.The S&P 500 financials sector (-0.8%) succumbed to broad-based selling interest throughout the day. Wells Fargo (WFC 48.28, -1.02, -2.1%) was a notable laggard amid a Wall Street Journal report indicating that the Trump administration plans to make it harder for deeply indebted borrowers to acquire mortgage loans.On the other hand, the S&P 500 defensive-oriented sectors -- utilities (+0.5%), real estate (+0.5%), health care (+0.4%), and consumer staples (+0.3%) -- were the lone sectors that finished higher.Separately, Mylan N.V. (MYL 20.78, +2.32, +12.6%) agreed to combine with Pfizer's (PFE 41.45, -1.64, -3.8%) off-patent drug business, giving Mylan shareholders 43% of the combined company. On a related note, Mylan N.V. beat top and bottom-line estimates; Pfizer beat earnings estimates but missed revenue estimates.U.S. Treasuries finished the session higher, pushing yields lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield declined three basis points each to 1.84% and 2.06%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index finished flat at 98.04. WTI crude increased 1.2% to $56.87/bbl.Investors did not receive any notable economic data on Monday.Looking ahead, Tuesday will feature the Personal Income and Spending report for June, which will include the Fed's preferred inflation gauge -- the PCE Price Index. Investors will also receive the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for July, Pending Home Sales for June, and the S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May.Nasdaq Composite +25.0% YTDS&P 500 +20.5% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +16.7% YTDRussell 2000 +16.4% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1472/1420. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1183/1867.Briefing.com is the leading Internet provider of live market analysis for U.S. Stock, U.S. Bond and world FX market participants. 1-800-752-3013 or http://www.briefing.comLoad-Date: July 30, 2019End of Document

DAX...12253.4...-164.10...-1.30%.16:15 ETDow +28.90 at 27221.35, Nasdaq -36.88 at 8293.33, S&P -4.89 at 3020.97[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 lost 0.2% on Monday, slipping from record highs in a lackluster session. The Nasdaq Composite (-0.4%) and Russell 2000 (-0.6%) both underperformed, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.1%) managed to finish higher.Monday's session didn't include much price action, as investors appeared to be waiting for several key events later this week. Some of these events will include the FOMC's rate decision, U.S.-China trade talks, the July employment report, and Apple's (AAPL 209.68, +1.94, +0.9%) earnings report. On a related note, Apple's price target was raised to $235 from $225 at UBS before its results after Tuesday's close.Apple shares rose on the increased price target, but the broader market was still weighed down by widely-held shares of Amazon (AMZN 1912.45, -30.60, -1.6%), Facebook (FB 195.94, -3.81, -1.9%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1239.41, -11.00, -0.9%). In turn, the S&P 500 consumer discretionary (-0.6%) and communication services (-0.5%) sectors were among today's laggards but, like the broader market, finished the session off intraday lows.The S&P 500 financials sector (-0.8%) succumbed to broad-based selling interest throughout the day. Wells Fargo (WFC 48.28, -1.02, -2.1%) was a notable laggard amid a Wall Street Journal report indicating that the Trump administration plans to make it harder for deeply indebted borrowers to acquire mortgage loans.On the other hand, the S&P 500 defensive-oriented sectors -- utilities (+0.5%), real estate (+0.5%), health care (+0.4%), and consumer staples (+0.3%) -- were the lone sectors that finished higher.Separately, Mylan N.V. (MYL 20.78, +2.32, +12.6%) agreed to combine with Pfizer's (PFE 41.45, -1.64, -3.8%) off-patent drug business, giving Mylan shareholders 43% of the combined company. On a related note, Mylan N.V. beat top and bottom-line estimates; Pfizer beat earnings estimates but missed revenue estimates.U.S. Treasuries finished the session higher, pushing yields lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield declined three basis points each to 1.84% and 2.06%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index finished flat at 98.04. WTI crude increased 1.2% to $56.87/bbl.Investors did not receive any notable economic data on Monday.Looking ahead, Tuesday will feature the Personal Income and Spending report for June, which will include the Fed's preferred inflation gauge -- the PCE Price Index. Investors will also receive the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for July, Pending Home Sales for June, and the S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May.Nasdaq Composite +25.0% YTDS&P 500 +20.5% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +16.7% YTDRussell 2000 +16.4% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1472/1420. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1183/1867.Briefing.com is the leading Internet provider of live market analysis for U.S. Stock, U.S. Bond and world FX market participants. 1-800-752-3013 or http://www.briefing.comLoad-Date: July 30, 2019End of Document

Dec: 1263Moving the MarketSector WatchSome consolidation from record highs in front of the Fed's rate decision tomorrowPresident Trump calls out China for not buying U.S. agricultural products; trade talks are ongoing in Shanghai Relative strength in the S&P 500 real estate and consumer staples sectorsStrongest consumer confidence reading since Nov. 2018Strong: Real Estate, Consumer Staples, Utilities, MaterialsWeak: Health Care, Consumer Discretionary, Financials12:55 ETDow -56.49 at 27164.86, Nasdaq -30.01 at 8263.32, S&P -11.00 at 3009.97[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market has wavered in negative territory today with the S&P 500 currently down 0.3%. There hasn't been much buying conviction in the broader market, although the small-cap Russell 2000 (+0.5%) has seen some positive action. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.2%, and the Nasdaq Composite is down 0.4%.Several factors that have contributed to the negative disposition include President Trump saying there are no signs of China buying U.S. agricultural products, some cautious trading ahead of Apple's (AAPL 208.08, -1.59, -0.8%) earnings report after the close and the Fed's rate decision tomorrow, and the disappointing price action in shares of Beyond Meat (BYND 205.01, -17.12, -7.7%) following its report.Beyond Meat is perhaps more a reflection of how far many stocks, and the stock market to a certain extent, have come in a short period of time. It isn't too surprising to see some broader consolidation -- or to see shares of Beyond Meat attempting a recovery after being down as much as 17% today.The stock market, too, has come off its lows. At this juncture, the utilities (-0.7%), information technology (-0.6%), and consumer discretionary (-0.6%) sectors are underperforming, while the materials (+0.5%), real estate (+0.5%), energy (+0.5%), and consumer staples (+0.4%) sectors are outperforming.In corporate news, Procter & Gamble (PG 121.29, +5.29, +4.6%) and Merck (MRK 83.42, +0.94, +1.1%) both beat top and bottom-line estimates. Shares are up nicely on the results, while shares of fellow Dow component Pfizer (PFE 39.02, -2.44) are down 5.9% after being downgraded at Bank of America/Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley. Capital One (COF 89.99, -6.93, -7.2%), meanwhile, is feeling the fallout from a data breach that affected over 100 million customers.Separately, an expectation that interest rates will remain low has prompted Goldman Sachs to raise its S&P 500 2019 year-end target to 3100 and set a 2020 year-end price target of 3400. Currently, the benchmark 10-yr yield is up one basis point to 2.07%.Reviewing today's economic data, which included the Personal Income and Spending Report for June, the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for July, the S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May, and Pending Home Sales for June:Personal income increased 0.4% (Briefing.com consensus 0.4%) while personal spending rose 0.3% (Briefing.com consensus 0.3%) m/m in June. The PCE Price Index was up 0.1%, as expected, and the core PCE price Index, which excludes food and energy, jumped 0.2%, also as expected. On a yr/yr basis, the PCE Price Index held steady at 1.4% while the core PCE Price Index edged up to 1.6% from 1.5% in May.The key takeaway from the report is that it contained decent consumer data and tame inflation data, which is not all that surprising relative to recent data seen of late.The Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index surged to 135.7 in July (Briefing.com consensus 125.5) from an upwardly revised 124.3 (from 121.5) in June. That is the highest reading since November 2018 and the third-highest reading since October 2000.The key takeaway from the report is that consumers are optimistic about current and prospective business and labor market conditions, and have improved expectations for their financial outlook. That is a supportive combination that will encourage increased consumer spending activity.The S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May increased 2.4% (Briefing.com consensus 3.5%) after increasing 2.5% in April.Pending Home Sales increased 1.6% in June (Briefing.com consensus +1.0%). DAX...12253.4...-164.10...-1.30%.16:15 ETDow +28.90 at 27221.35, Nasdaq -36.88 at 8293.33, S&P -4.89 at 3020.97[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 lost 0.2% on Monday, slipping from record highs in a lackluster session. The Nasdaq Composite (-0.4%) and Russell 2000 (-0.6%) both underperformed, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.1%) managed to finish higher.Monday's session didn't include much price action, as investors appeared to be waiting for several key events later this week. Some of these events will include the FOMC's rate decision, U.S.-China trade talks, the July employment report, and Apple's (AAPL 209.68, +1.94, +0.9%) earnings report. On a related note, Apple's price target was raised to $235 from $225 at UBS before its results after Tuesday's close.Apple shares rose on the increased price target, but the broader market was still weighed down by widely-held shares of Amazon (AMZN 1912.45, -30.60, -1.6%), Facebook (FB 195.94, -3.81, -1.9%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1239.41, -11.00, -0.9%). In turn, the S&P 500 consumer discretionary (-0.6%) and communication services (-0.5%) sectors were among today's laggards but, like the broader market, finished the session off intraday lows.The S&P 500 financials sector (-0.8%) succumbed to broad-based selling interest throughout the day. Wells Fargo (WFC 48.28, -1.02, -2.1%) was a notable laggard amid a Wall Street Journal report indicating that the Trump administration plans to make it harder for deeply indebted borrowers to acquire mortgage loans.On the other hand, the S&P 500 defensive-oriented sectors -- utilities (+0.5%), real estate (+0.5%), health care (+0.4%), and consumer staples (+0.3%) -- were the lone sectors that finished higher.Separately, Mylan N.V. (MYL 20.78, +2.32, +12.6%) agreed to combine with Pfizer's (PFE 41.45, -1.64, -3.8%) off-patent drug business, giving Mylan shareholders 43% of the combined company. On a related note, Mylan N.V. beat top and bottom-line estimates; Pfizer beat earnings estimates but missed revenue estimates.U.S. Treasuries finished the session higher, pushing yields lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield declined three basis points each to 1.84% and 2.06%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index finished flat at 98.04. WTI crude increased 1.2% to $56.87/bbl.Investors did not receive any notable economic data on Monday.Looking ahead, Tuesday will feature the Personal Income and Spending report for June, which will include the Fed's preferred inflation gauge -- the PCE Price Index. Investors will also receive the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for July, Pending Home Sales for June, and the S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May.Nasdaq Composite +25.0% YTDS&P 500 +20.5% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +16.7% YTDRussell 2000 +16.4% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1472/1420. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1183/1867.Briefing.com is the leading Internet provider of live market analysis for U.S. Stock, U.S. Bond and world FX market participants. 1-800-752-3013 or http://www.briefing.comLoad-Date: July 30, 2019End of Document

S&P: -11.00...NYSE Vol: 303.3 mln.. Adv: 1495.. Dec: 1388Nasdaq Vol: 898.9 mln.. Adv: 1702.. Dec: 1263Moving the MarketSector WatchSome consolidation from record highs in front Apple's (AAPL) earnings report after the close and the Fed's rate decision tomorrowPresident Trump calls out China for not buying U.S. agricultural products; trade talks are ongoing in Shanghai Strongest consumer confidence reading since Nov. 2018Strong: Energy, Real Estate, Materials, Consumer StaplesWeak: Utilities, Communication Services, Consumer Discretionary, Information Technology12:55 ETDow -56.49 at 27164.86, Nasdaq -30.01 at 8263.32, S&P -11.00 at 3009.97[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market has wavered in negative territory today with the S&P 500 currently down 0.3%. There hasn't been much buying conviction in the broader market, although the small-cap Russell 2000 (+0.5%) has seen some positive action. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.2%, and the Nasdaq Composite is down 0.4%.Several factors that have contributed to the negative disposition include President Trump saying there are no signs of China buying U.S. agricultural products, some cautious trading ahead of Apple's (AAPL 208.08, -1.59, -0.8%) earnings report after the close and the Fed's rate decision tomorrow, and the disappointing price action in shares of Beyond Meat (BYND 205.01, -17.12, -7.7%) following its report.Beyond Meat is perhaps more a reflection of how far many stocks, and the stock market to a certain extent, have come in a short period of time. It isn't too surprising to see some broader consolidation -- or to see shares of Beyond Meat attempting a recovery after being down as much as 17% today.The stock market, too, has come off its lows. At this juncture, the utilities (-0.7%), information technology (-0.6%), and consumer discretionary (-0.6%) sectors are underperforming, while the materials (+0.5%), real estate (+0.5%), energy (+0.5%), and consumer staples (+0.4%) sectors are outperforming.In corporate news, Procter & Gamble (PG 121.29, +5.29, +4.6%) and Merck (MRK 83.42, +0.94, +1.1%) both beat top and bottom-line estimates. Shares are up nicely on the results, while shares of fellow Dow component Pfizer (PFE 39.02, -2.44) are down 5.9% after being downgraded at Bank of America/Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley. Capital One (COF 89.99, -6.93, -7.2%), meanwhile, is feeling the fallout from a data breach that affected over 100 million customers.Separately, an expectation that interest rates will remain low has prompted Goldman Sachs to raise its S&P 500 2019 year-end target to 3100 and set a 2020 year-end price target of 3400. Currently, the benchmark 10-yr note yield is up one basis point to 2.07%.Reviewing today's economic data, which included the Personal Income and Spending Report for June, the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for July, the S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May, and Pending Home Sales for June:Personal income increased 0.4% (Briefing.com consensus 0.4%) while personal spending rose 0.3% (Briefing.com consensus 0.3%) m/m in June. The PCE Price Index was up 0.1%, as expected, and the core PCE price Index, which excludes food and energy, jumped 0.2%, also as expected. On a yr/yr basis, the PCE Price Index held steady at 1.4% while the core PCE Price Index edged up to 1.6% from 1.5% in May.The key takeaway from the report is that it contained decent consumer data and tame inflation data, which is not all that surprising relative to recent data seen of late.The Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index surged to 135.7 in July (Briefing.com consensus 125.5) from an upwardly revised 124.3 (from 121.5) in June. That is the highest reading since November 2018 and the third-highest reading since October 2000.The key takeaway from the report is that consumers are optimistic about current and prospective business and labor market conditions, and have improved expectations for their financial outlook. That is a supportive combination that will encourage increased consumer spending activity.The S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May increased 2.4% (Briefing.com consensus 3.5%) after increasing 2.5% in April.Pending Home Sales increased 1.6% in June (Briefing.com consensus +1.0%).
