The Dow Jones Industrial Average, which underperformed last week, is up 0.2%.Broadly-speaking, there isn't too much conviction in the market today in front of an eventful week. Notable events, among many things, will include the FOMC's rate decision, the July employment report, and U.S.-China trade talks. While trade expectations are low, partly due to President Trump saying he doesn't expect a deal until after the 2020 presidential election, rate-cut expectations are high.In the meantime, widely-held shares of Amazon (AMZN 1898.19, -44.85, -2.3%), Facebook (FB 196.16, -3.58, -1.9%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1234.91, -15.50, -1.2%) are down noticeably and have contributed to the underperformance of the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 consumer discretionary (-0.9%) and communication services (-0.7%) sectors.There are no specific news drivers to account for their underperformance today. It could be some unwinding from crowded positions that were mentioned in a report from The Wall Street Journal, or a form of profit taking after Alphabet shares surged more than 10% following earnings on Friday.On the other hand, the S&P 500 real estate (+0.5%), health care (+0.4%), and consumer staples (+0.1%) sectors have provided some support for the broader market.In addition, shares of Apple (AAPL 210.06, +2.32, +1.1%) are up over 1% after UBS increased its price target to $235 from $225 ahead of its earnings report after Tuesday's close. Its outperformance has provided influential support for the S&P 500, Nasdaq, and Dow.Separately, Mylan N.V. (MYL 21.05, +2.58, +14.0%) agreed to combine with Pfizer's (PFE 42.38, -0.71, -1.7%) off-patent drug business, giving Mylan shareholders 43% of the combined company. On a related note, Mylan N.V. beat top and bottom-line estimates, while Pfizer beat earnings estimates but missed revenue estimates.Investors did not receive any notable economic data today.12:25 ETDow +41.54 at 27233.99, Nasdaq -58.40 at 8271.81, S&P -7.25 at 3018.61[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades down 0.2% and has wavered in negative territory all session.Looking at the FAANG stocks shows Apple (AAPL 210.41, +2.67, +1.3%) as the lone stock trading higher after its price target was raised to $235 from $225 at UBS ahead of its earnings report.Amazon (AMZN 1893.55, -50.60, -2.6%) is down more than 2.5% followed by Facebook (FB 196.01, -3.74, -1.9%), Netflix (NFLX 331.38, -4.40, -1.3%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1232.45, -17.96, -1.4%), which are also down noticieably. DAX...12408.51...-11.40...-0.10%.16:15 ETDow +51.47 at 27192.45, Nasdaq +91.67 at 8330.21, S&P +22.19 at 3025.86[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market wrapped up the week on a high note, as upbeat results from Alphabet (GOOG 1250.41, +118.29, +10.5%) and encouraging Q2 GDP data helped lift the S&P 500 (+0.7%) and Nasdaq Composite (+1.1%) to record closes. The Russell 2000 rose 1.1%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average increased just 0.2%.Friday's session, much like in the days before, included its fair share of better-than-expected earnings reports. Alphabet gets the lead due to its mega-cap status, but honorable mentions include Starbucks (SBUX 99.11, +8.13, +8.9%) and Twitter (TWTR 41.80, +3.68, +9.7%). Dow components Intel (INTC 51.59, -0.57, -1.1%) and McDonald's (MCD 215.58, +1.14, +0.5%) underperformed despite positive results.Besides earnings, the fact that the U.S. economy continues to grow at a healthy pace was a positive consideration for investors. The advance estimate for second-quarter GDP increased 2.1% (Briefing.com consensus 1.8%), which did mark a modest slowdown from last quarter but not as much as expected due to strong consumer spending.The S&P 500 communication services sector (+3.3%), which is home to Alphabet and Twitter, nearly tripled the advance in the runner-up consumer staples sector (+1.2%). Laggards included energy (-0.5%) and industrials (-0.2%), although losses were modest.Amazon (AMZN 1942.70, -31.22, -1.6%) was also left out of the advance after the company missed profit estimates and guided Q3 operating income below expectations.In corporate news, Intel confirmed that Apple (AAPL 207.74, +0.72, +0.4%) will acquire most of its smartphone modem chip business for $1 billion. 3M (MMM 173.98, -4.15, -2.3%) disclosed an internal investigation to determine if its expenditures may have violated the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The Department of Justice approved the merger between T-Mobile US (TMUS 84.25, +4.34, +5.4%) and Sprint (S 7.99, +0.55, +7.4%).U.S. Treasuries finished the session with slight losses, pushing yields higher. The 2-yr yield increased two basis points to 1.87%, and the 10-yr yield increased one basis point to 2.08%. The U.S. Dollar Index advanced 0.2% to 98.01. WTI crude increased 0.3% to $56.19/bbl.Reviewing the Q2 GDP data, which was Friday's lone economic report:According to the BEA, the advance estimate showed Q2 real GDP increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2.1% (Briefing.com consensus 1.8%) following a 3.1% increase in the first quarter. The GDP Price Deflator was up 2.4% (Briefing.com consensus 1.8%) after increasing 1.1% in the first quarter.The key takeaway from the report is that it revealed some impressive strength in the U.S. consumer, evidenced by the 4.3% growth in personal consumption expenditures (PCE), which was the second highest over the past 16 quarters. PCE contributed 2.85 percentage points to Q2 GDP growth.Investors will not receive any economic data of note on Monday.Nasdaq Composite +25.5% YTDS&P 500 +20.7% YTDRussell 2000 +17.1% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +16.6% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1963/922. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 2099/928.Briefing.com is the leading Internet provider of live market analysis for U.S. Stock, U.S. Bond and world FX market participants. 1-800-752-3013 or http://www.briefing.comLoad-Date: July 29, 2019End of Document

DAX...12408.51...-11.40...-0.10%.16:15 ETDow +51.47 at 27192.45, Nasdaq +91.67 at 8330.21, S&P +22.19 at 3025.86[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market wrapped up the week on a high note, as upbeat results from Alphabet (GOOG 1250.41, +118.29, +10.5%) and encouraging Q2 GDP data helped lift the S&P 500 (+0.7%) and Nasdaq Composite (+1.1%) to record closes. The Russell 2000 rose 1.1%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average increased just 0.2%.Friday's session, much like in the days before, included its fair share of better-than-expected earnings reports. Alphabet gets the lead due to its mega-cap status, but honorable mentions include Starbucks (SBUX 99.11, +8.13, +8.9%) and Twitter (TWTR 41.80, +3.68, +9.7%). Dow components Intel (INTC 51.59, -0.57, -1.1%) and McDonald's (MCD 215.58, +1.14, +0.5%) underperformed despite positive results.Besides earnings, the fact that the U.S. economy continues to grow at a healthy pace was a positive consideration for investors. The advance estimate for second-quarter GDP increased 2.1% (Briefing.com consensus 1.8%), which did mark a modest slowdown from last quarter but not as much as expected due to strong consumer spending.The S&P 500 communication services sector (+3.3%), which is home to Alphabet and Twitter, nearly tripled the advance in the runner-up consumer staples sector (+1.2%). Laggards included energy (-0.5%) and industrials (-0.2%), although losses were modest.Amazon (AMZN 1942.70, -31.22, -1.6%) was also left out of the advance after the company missed profit estimates and guided Q3 operating income below expectations.In corporate news, Intel confirmed that Apple (AAPL 207.74, +0.72, +0.4%) will acquire most of its smartphone modem chip business for $1 billion. 3M (MMM 173.98, -4.15, -2.3%) disclosed an internal investigation to determine if its expenditures may have violated the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The Department of Justice approved the merger between T-Mobile US (TMUS 84.25, +4.34, +5.4%) and Sprint (S 7.99, +0.55, +7.4%).U.S. Treasuries finished the session with slight losses, pushing yields higher. The 2-yr yield increased two basis points to 1.87%, and the 10-yr yield increased one basis point to 2.08%. The U.S. Dollar Index advanced 0.2% to 98.01. WTI crude increased 0.3% to $56.19/bbl.Reviewing the Q2 GDP data, which was Friday's lone economic report:According to the BEA, the advance estimate showed Q2 real GDP increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2.1% (Briefing.com consensus 1.8%) following a 3.1% increase in the first quarter. The GDP Price Deflator was up 2.4% (Briefing.com consensus 1.8%) after increasing 1.1% in the first quarter.The key takeaway from the report is that it revealed some impressive strength in the U.S. consumer, evidenced by the 4.3% growth in personal consumption expenditures (PCE), which was the second highest over the past 16 quarters. PCE contributed 2.85 percentage points to Q2 GDP growth.Investors will not receive any economic data of note on Monday.Nasdaq Composite +25.5% YTDS&P 500 +20.7% YTDRussell 2000 +17.1% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +16.6% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1963/922. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 2099/928.Briefing.com is the leading Internet provider of live market analysis for U.S. Stock, U.S. Bond and world FX market participants. 1-800-752-3013 or http://www.briefing.comLoad-Date: July 29, 2019End of Document

DAX...12408.51...-11.40...-0.10%.16:15 ETDow +51.47 at 27192.45, Nasdaq +91.67 at 8330.21, S&P +22.19 at 3025.86[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market wrapped up the week on a high note, as upbeat results from Alphabet (GOOG 1250.41, +118.29, +10.5%) and encouraging Q2 GDP data helped lift the S&P 500 (+0.7%) and Nasdaq Composite (+1.1%) to record closes. The Russell 2000 rose 1.1%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average increased just 0.2%.Friday's session, much like in the days before, included its fair share of better-than-expected earnings reports. Alphabet gets the lead due to its mega-cap status, but honorable mentions include Starbucks (SBUX 99.11, +8.13, +8.9%) and Twitter (TWTR 41.80, +3.68, +9.7%). Dow components Intel (INTC 51.59, -0.57, -1.1%) and McDonald's (MCD 215.58, +1.14, +0.5%) underperformed despite positive results.Besides earnings, the fact that the U.S. economy continues to grow at a healthy pace was a positive consideration for investors. The advance estimate for second-quarter GDP increased 2.1% (Briefing.com consensus 1.8%), which did mark a modest slowdown from last quarter but not as much as expected due to strong consumer spending.The S&P 500 communication services sector (+3.3%), which is home to Alphabet and Twitter, nearly tripled the advance in the runner-up consumer staples sector (+1.2%). Laggards included energy (-0.5%) and industrials (-0.2%), although losses were modest.Amazon (AMZN 1942.70, -31.22, -1.6%) was also left out of the advance after the company missed profit estimates and guided Q3 operating income below expectations.In corporate news, Intel confirmed that Apple (AAPL 207.74, +0.72, +0.4%) will acquire most of its smartphone modem chip business for $1 billion. 3M (MMM 173.98, -4.15, -2.3%) disclosed an internal investigation to determine if its expenditures may have violated the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The Department of Justice approved the merger between T-Mobile US (TMUS 84.25, +4.34, +5.4%) and Sprint (S 7.99, +0.55, +7.4%).U.S. Treasuries finished the session with slight losses, pushing yields higher. The 2-yr yield increased two basis points to 1.87%, and the 10-yr yield increased one basis point to 2.08%. The U.S. Dollar Index advanced 0.2% to 98.01. WTI crude increased 0.3% to $56.19/bbl.Reviewing the Q2 GDP data, which was Friday's lone economic report:According to the BEA, the advance estimate showed Q2 real GDP increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2.1% (Briefing.com consensus 1.8%) following a 3.1% increase in the first quarter. The GDP Price Deflator was up 2.4% (Briefing.com consensus 1.8%) after increasing 1.1% in the first quarter.The key takeaway from the report is that it revealed some impressive strength in the U.S. consumer, evidenced by the 4.3% growth in personal consumption expenditures (PCE), which was the second highest over the past 16 quarters. PCE contributed 2.85 percentage points to Q2 GDP growth.Investors will not receive any economic data of note on Monday.Nasdaq Composite +25.5% YTDS&P 500 +20.7% YTDRussell 2000 +17.1% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +16.6% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1963/922. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 2099/928.Briefing.com is the leading Internet provider of live market analysis for U.S. Stock, U.S. Bond and world FX market participants. 1-800-752-3013 or http://www.briefing.comLoad-Date: July 29, 2019End of Document

Another bank bailout took place in China, as three major banks acquired a nearly 20.0% stake in Bank of Jinzhou. This comes after the Chinese government seized Baoshang Bank in June. China's Securities Regulatory Commission suspended more than 40 IPOs due to a concern that the country's second largest auditor falsified information regarding these listings. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said it is unlikely that he will meet with South Korea's President Moon Jae-in at the UN meeting in September unless South Korea takes "constructive steps" to improve relations between the two countries.In economic data: Japan's June Retail Sales +0.5% yr/yr (expected 0.2%; last 1.3%) Australia's Q2 HIA New Home Sales -12.4% yr/yr (last 28.8%)---Equity Markets---Japan's Nikkei: -0.4% Hong Kong's Hang Seng: -1.0% China's Shanghai Composite: -0.1% India's Sensex: -0.5% South Korea's Kospi: -1.8% Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.5%Major European indices trade near their flat lines while the U.K.'s FTSE (+1.9%) outperforms, rising to a fresh high for the year as the pound hits its lowest level in more than two years. Shares of London Stock Exchange have jumped nearly 15.0% after the exchange confirmed that it is in talks to acquire Refinitiv. British Foreign Secretary, Dominic Raab, said that the Irish backstop cannot be part of the withdrawal agreement, adding that preparations for a no-deal Brexit are being stepped up. There was renewed speculation that members of Italy's Lega party are pushing Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini to force an early election.In economic data: U.K.'s June Mortgage Lending GBP3.73 bln (expected GBP3.40 bln; last GBP2.94 bln) and June Mortgage Approvals 66,440 (expected 65,750; last 65,650). June BoE Consumer Credit GBP1.046 bln (expected GPB900 mln; last GBP906 mln). Spain's July CPI -0.6% m/m (expected 0.2%; last -0.1%); +0.5% yr/yr (expected 0.6%; last 0.4%). June Retail Sales +2.4% yr/yr (last 2.6%) Italy's June PPI -0.3% m/m (expected -0.1%; last 0.1%); +0.9% yr/yr, as expected (last 1.5%)---Equity Markets---STOXX Europe 600: +0.4% Germany's DAX: +0.1% U.K.'s FTSE 100: +1.9% France's CAC 40: +0.1% Italy's FTSE MIB: -0.3% Spain's IBEX 35: UNCH08:27 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -1.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -4.40.The S&P 500 futures trade two points, or 0.1%, below fair value. The S&P 500 is up 2.9% in July with three trading sessions left.Reviewing the S&P 500 sector standing this month shows information technology (+5.6%) and communication services (+5.4%) leading the benchmark index higher. Conversely, the energy (-2.1%) and health care (-0.7%) sectors are the lone sectors in negative territory this month.Separately, shares of PayPal (PYPL 113.60, -1.89) are down 1.6% in pre-market action after the stock was downgraded to Sell from Neutral at Guggenheim.07:56 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -0.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -4.10.The S&P 500 futures trade roughly in-line with fair value ahead of an eventful week on Wall Street. The week will feature the FOMC's rate decision on Wednesday, the July employment report on Friday, and earnings reports throughout the week.U.S.-China trade talks will also resume on Tuesday for a two-day meeting in Beijing, but expectations for the high-level meeting are low. On the other hand, the Fed will kick off its two-day policy meeting tomorrow, and expectations are high for a rate cut of at least 25 basis points at the conclusion of the meeting.It isn't too surprising to see some hesitation this morning ahead of these potential market-moving events, especially after the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite hit new all-time highs on Friday. Also, while there will be no notable economic data released today, there are some health care corporate news for investors to parse through.Dow component Pfizer (PFE 42.45, -0.64, -1.5%) missed revenue estimates and lowered its full-year guidance to reflect anticipated completions of prior acquisitions. In addition, Mylan N.V. (MYL 21.55, +3.09, +16.7%) will combine with Pfizer's off-patent drug business with Mylan shareholders owning 43% of the combined company.U.S. Treasuries have edged higher, pushing yields lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield are down three basis points each to 1.84% and 2.05%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index is up 0.1% to 98.11. WTI crude is up 0.1% to $56.23/bbl.In U.S. Corporate news:Pfizer (PFE 42.45, -0.64): -1.5% after missing revenue estimates and lowering its guidance for FY19 to reflect prior acquisitions. Mylan N.V. (MYL 21.55, +3.09): +16.7% after agreeing to combine with Pfizer's off-patent branded and generic established medicines business. Pfizer shareholders will own 57% of the combined company, while Mylan shareholders will own 43%. Exact Sciences (EXAS 107.00, -10.92): -9.3% after announcing that it will combine with Genomic Health (GHDX 69.70, +1.04, +1.5%) for $72.00 per share in a cash and stock transaction valued at $2.8 billion. Genomic Health and Exact Sciences beat top and bottom-line estimates and each raised their full-year guidance.Reviewing overnight developments:Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region began the week on a mixed note. Hang Seng...28106.41...-291.30...-1.00%.07:03 ETMarket is Closed[BRIEFING.COM] FTSE...7532.76...+43.70...+0.60%. DAX...12408.51...-11.40...-0.10%.16:15 ETDow +51.47 at 27192.45, Nasdaq +91.67 at 8330.21, S&P +22.19 at 3025.86[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market wrapped up the week on a high note, as upbeat results from Alphabet (GOOG 1250.41, +118.29, +10.5%) and encouraging Q2 GDP data helped lift the S&P 500 (+0.7%) and Nasdaq Composite (+1.1%) to record closes. The Russell 2000 rose 1.1%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average increased just 0.2%.Friday's session, much like in the days before, included its fair share of better-than-expected earnings reports. Alphabet gets the lead due to its mega-cap status, but honorable mentions include Starbucks (SBUX 99.11, +8.13, +8.9%) and Twitter (TWTR 41.80, +3.68, +9.7%). Dow components Intel (INTC 51.59, -0.57, -1.1%) and McDonald's (MCD 215.58, +1.14, +0.5%) underperformed despite positive results.Besides earnings, the fact that the U.S. economy continues to grow at a healthy pace was a positive consideration for investors. The advance estimate for second-quarter GDP increased 2.1% (Briefing.com consensus 1.8%), which did mark a modest slowdown from last quarter but not as much as expected due to strong consumer spending.The S&P 500 communication services sector (+3.3%), which is home to Alphabet and Twitter, nearly tripled the advance in the runner-up consumer staples sector (+1.2%). Laggards included energy (-0.5%) and industrials (-0.2%), although losses were modest.Amazon (AMZN 1942.70, -31.22, -1.6%) was also left out of the advance after the company missed profit estimates and guided Q3 operating income below expectations.In corporate news, Intel confirmed that Apple (AAPL 207.74, +0.72, +0.4%) will acquire most of its smartphone modem chip business for $1 billion. 3M (MMM 173.98, -4.15, -2.3%) disclosed an internal investigation to determine if its expenditures may have violated the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The Department of Justice approved the merger between T-Mobile US (TMUS 84.25, +4.34, +5.4%) and Sprint (S 7.99, +0.55, +7.4%).U.S. Treasuries finished the session with slight losses, pushing yields higher. The 2-yr yield increased two basis points to 1.87%, and the 10-yr yield increased one basis point to 2.08%. The U.S. Dollar Index advanced 0.2% to 98.01. WTI crude increased 0.3% to $56.19/bbl.Reviewing the Q2 GDP data, which was Friday's lone economic report:According to the BEA, the advance estimate showed Q2 real GDP increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2.1% (Briefing.com consensus 1.8%) following a 3.1% increase in the first quarter. The GDP Price Deflator was up 2.4% (Briefing.com consensus 1.8%) after increasing 1.1% in the first quarter.The key takeaway from the report is that it revealed some impressive strength in the U.S. consumer, evidenced by the 4.3% growth in personal consumption expenditures (PCE), which was the second highest over the past 16 quarters. PCE contributed 2.85 percentage points to Q2 GDP growth.Investors will not receive any economic data of note on Monday.Nasdaq Composite +25.5% YTDS&P 500 +20.7% YTDRussell 2000 +17.1% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +16.6% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1963/922. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 2099/928.Briefing.com is the leading Internet provider of live market analysis for U.S. Stock, U.S. Bond and world FX market participants. 1-800-752-3013 or http://www.briefing.comLoad-Date: July 29, 2019End of Document| About LexisNexis | Privacy Policy | Terms & Conditions | Copyright © 2021 LexisNexis Page 25 of 714Media Analyses: Restart Of US-China Talks, Ease Of Huawei Ban Boosts US Stocks  Page 28 of 714Trump attacks on Google recycle baseless claims  Page 31 of 714Trump attacks on Google recycle baseless claims  Page  of China donates office equipment to Cambodia's Preah Sihanouk Provincial Hall  Page 45 of 714Sinovac Reports Unaudited Second Quarter 2019 Financial Results  Page 48 of 714Oranco, Inc.
